name: New Zealand: Proportion of Maori Ethnic Population by Region
title: Proportions of Maori Ethnic Population by Region
description:
According to the 2006 New Zealand Census:
• 87.0 percent of Maori people lived in the North Island and 24.3 percent lived in the Auckland Region as of 2006.
• Since the 2001 New Zealand census, an increase of 8,580 people have been recognized in the South Island. This has resulted in a population density of 73,230 as of 2006.
• The highest distribution of Maori is identified in four major areas. 64.4 percent of Māori occupy the Chatham Islands Territory, 61.1 percent occupy the Kawerau district, 60.7 percent occupy the Wairoa district, and 59.3 percent live in the Opotiki district.
• In 2006, 84.4 percent of Māori living in New Zealand occupied urban areas, compared to a 1956 demographic which states that approximately two-thirds of this ethnic group occupied rural territories in the mid 20th century.
Note: The Māori ethnic population includes those people who stated Māori as being their sole ethnic group or one of several ethnic groups.
license: Public usage permitted. For further copyright information, click [here](http://www.stats.govt.nz/about_us/about-this-site/copyright-terms-of-use.aspx).

name: Macro-Ge groups Brazil (Public Content)
title: Macro-Gê Groups
description:
Illustrated on this map is the distribution of Kali'na in
South America. This language is mostly spoken in rural communities
throughout the northeastern area of the continent. The speakers constitute
an extremely small minority in the countries they inhabit, residing
in what is only a fraction of their pre-Columbian territory.
datasource:
[CIA World Factbook. Carte I Ethnies Amérindiennes de la grande
  Amazonie (L.Vemt). ](http://www.ulb.ac.be/soco/apft/GEO/amaz2.htm)

name: Australia: Language Subgroups (Oates and Oates)
title: Aboriginal Languages of Australia: Language Subgroups
description: This map shows the aboriginal language subgroups in Australia based on the map prepared by Oates and Oates and supplemented with information from the following source: "Languages of the World: Indo-Pacific Fascicle Six" by Geoffrey N. O'Grady and C.F. and F.M. Voegelin.
source: Oates, William J. and Lynette F. Oates, editors. 1970. A revised linguistic survey of Australia. Australian Aboriginal Studies, 12. Canberra: Australian Institute for Aboriginal Studies. Adapted from a basic classification prepared in 1966 by G.N. O'Grady, S.A. Wurm, and K.L. Hale; drawn by R.M. Watt for the Dept. of Linguistics, Univeristy of Victoria, B.C., Canada.

name: Fiji: Pidgins, Creoles and Lingua Francas
title: Fiji: Pidgins, Creoles and Lingua Francas
description:
Two pidgin varieties exist in Fiji: Pidgin Hindi and Modern Pidgin Fijian.  Both pidgins are thought to have approximately 50000 speakers each. This map shows the distribution of both varieties within Fiji.
This original map was made by vectorizing data from the MultiTree language database and the Atlas of the World's Languages.
related: This folder (Australia and the Pacific: Pidgins, Creoles and Lingua Francas) contains other maps which show the distribution of varieties spoken in this region.  These maps can be observed side-by-side.

name: Isogloss map for -s- aspiration in Iberian Peninsula Spanish, according to ALPI .
description:
The -s- (and -z-) aspiration is considered one of the 2 key dialectal markers for Spanish, along with /s/ and /z/ distinction. In fact, there seems to be a relationship between both characteristics. Though the map reflects isolated cases of -s- aspiration in northern Spain, it's likely that they stem from some kind of contact with southern speakers. For most northern speakers, the -s- aspiration was a pretty sure way to detect a southerner. Today the -s- aspirating variety of the language is expanding quickly to the north in Spain.
The words registered in the ALPI surveys that have been used in this map are :
desbocado (ALPI map 65)
castillo (ALPI map 37)
desnudo (ALPI map 66)
avispa (ALPI map 19)
source: Jota, Martin. January 2007. Isogloss map for -s- aspiration in Iberian Peninsula Spanish, according to ALPI, September 2011. Online: [http://www.jotamartin.byethost33.com/alpi_aspira_e.php.](http://www.jotamartin.byethost33.com/alpi_aspira_e.php)
datasource: Heap, David. 2003. Linguistics Atlas of the Iberian Peninsula. Ontario: University of Western Ontario. Online: [ http://westernlinguistics.ca/alpi/.](http://westernlinguistics.ca/alpi/)
license: The reproduction and use of the data collected in these pages is explicitly authorised, exclusively for research or teaching purposes, provided this copyright notice is included in any publication, the source (www.alpi.ca) is always cited, and provided that there is no charge for the data beyond the normal price of the physical medium (if applicable). All sales, marketing or other for-profit uses of these data are specifically forbidden.

name: New Zealand: Iwi Tribal Areas (TAKOA)
title: Rohe Iwi O Aotearoa - Map of Tribal Areas
description:
This map designates the boundaries of Iwi tribal areas as well as its respective regional groupings (labeled in capital letters).
		 		
		The boundaries are based on knowledge only - they have no official standing (TAKOA).		
		 	
		Note: This map contains data on both sides of the 180th Parallel. Because of constraints on the base map, maps like this will not automatically zoom properly. More label information may be available at higher resolution, which may be viewed by zooming in on the map.
datasource: Boundaries are from a variety of sources referred to in extract 1.3.2 of the Atlas of New Zealand Boundaries, date of information, June 1988 (TAKOA).

name: Languages of Detroit
title: US Census: Languages of Detroit
description:
This work was produced by Ljuba Veselinova and Jason Booza, who mapped the more than 90 languages spoken in the Detroit 
Metropolitan Area (Oakland, Macomb and Wayne counties in southeast Michigan). The maps are based on data from the 2000 US Census. 
The census data had to be split in two groups: one for individual languages, and one to include the various groupings done in the 
census summaries. Most of the data for individual languages are available on the tract level.
A list of all the languages specified in the census data can be found on [
the project website](http://ling-map.ling.su.se/website/Detroit/DetroitLanguages.htm).
license: Ljuba Veselinova and Jason Booza hold copyright of this particular implementation of the otherwise freely available US Census Data.
creator: Ljuba Veselinova

name: Australia: Language Locations and Tribal Groups (Dixon and Blake)
title: Language Locations and Tribal Groups in Australia
description:
This is a compilation of six different maps showing various language locations and tribal groups in the Australia region.
		The Wargamay map displays the Wargamay language and its dialects as well as the neighboring languages. 
		According to Dixon, Wargamay, Hinchinbrook Biyay, and Halifax Biyay are all dialects of the Wargamay language. 
		He also explains that there are strong similarities between Wargamay and the bordering languages of Giramay and Nyawaygi,
		but these similarities do not suggest a "close genetic connection" (Dixon).
		The dialectal boundary between Biyay and Halifax Biyay are based loosely on information provided by the source. 
		The Watjarri map illustrates the Watjarri language, "spoken by the descendants of an Aboriginal tribe previously 
		camped along a section of the Murchison River," and its respective neighboring languages and place names (Douglas). 
		Around these stations and towns, within the original Watjarri area, were formed dialects. Furthermore, the railway 
		allowed for influences from other surrounding languages which Douglas describes is evident in the borrowings across 
		vocabularies. The Tasmania map shows a speculative inference of the different locations of the languages and dialects 
		of Tasmania which are now extinct. 
		On the map are 15 regions to which vocabulary are assigned and cross-compared to 
		analyze the genetic relationship between the languages. Crowley and Dixon suggest that there were at least eight languages 
		within Tasmania; however, this conclusion is "tentative" as little data is available on many of the languages. The 
		Margany/Gunya map displays Margany and Gunya, "the south-westernmost of the long chain of closely related dialects known 
		to (...) linguists as the Mari languages" and other surrounding languages and place names (Breen). The Anguthimiri map 
		highlights the area of Anguthimri speaking groups as well as neighboring peoples and languages. According to Crowley, 
		Anguthimri has "one of the most unusual phonological systems" consisting of single-syllable words, consonant clustered
		initial syllables, and an extensive vowel system (Crowley).
related:
[Aboriginal Languages of Australia: Language Families (Oates and Oates)](ContributionTable#cldf:12207)
[Aboriginal Languages of Australia: Language Groups (Oates and Oates)](ContributionTable#cldf:12208)

[Aboriginal Languages of Australia: Languages and Dialects](ContributionTable#cldf:12206)

name: Northern North America: Algic: Time of contact
title: Algic in Northern North America at the Time of Contact
description: The polygons represent areas where Algic languages were spoken when they were first encountered and knowledge of them was recorded by Europeans. This original map was made by vectorizing data from the MultiTree language database and the Atlas of the World's Languages.
related: This folder, "Northern North America: Time of Contact", contains other maps showing linguistic subgroups at the time of contact.  The maps may be overlaid on each other for a more complete picture. In addition, the folder "North America: Time of Contact" contains a map showing the southern distribution of Algic languages at the time of contact.

name: Balkans: Ancient Languages
title: Languages of the Ancient Balkans
description:
This map is an attempt to collect in one place all information available on the geographic location of 
		the ancient languages of the Balkans.  Since no single map included all the regions shown here, this map 
		is an amalgamation of material from a number of different sources. Since no hard data is available, the 
		location of the languages must be seen as approximate.
source:
woodard2004
Katičić , Radoslav. 1976. Ancient Languages of the Balkans. Mouton: The Hague
[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek_dialects)
[Illyria](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illyrians)
[Paionia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paionia)

name: South Pacific: Eastern Polynesia
title: South Pacific: Eastern Polynesia
description:
This map depicts languages of the Polynesian and Central-Eastern Oceanic subgroups of the Austronesian language families, as spoken in the Polynesian islands. These islands are in the southern portion of the region, often referred to as 'French Polynesia'. The Austronesian area spans from Madagascar in the west to Hawaii and Easter Island in the east. As it crosses the 180th parallel, this map will need to be viewed as eastern and western sections.
This original map was made by vectorizing data from the MultiTree language database and the Atlas of the World's Languages.

name: Austronesian Languages' Map
North America: Consolidation of the Northern Iroquois
title: Consolidation of the Northern Iroquois
description: This map shows the Northern Iroquois territory from c. 1000 and the consolidated Iroquois settlements from c. 1500. The Northern Iroquois around 1000 CE were distributed over Western Pennsylvania, New York and Southern Canada from the Upper Lawrence River to Lake Huron. In the following centuries the scattered Iroquois settlements contracted into thirteen tribal areas. This consolidation resulted from both periodic intertribal warfare and the development of agriculture. Trade routes linked the tribal areas and their villages. In a successful effort to halt intertribal conflict, around 1570, five central New York tribes - the Mohawk, Oneida, Onondoga, Cayuga and Seneca formed the Iroquois Confederacy (Flanders 1998: 17).

name: New Britain, 1947-1959. Ethnic groups.
Linguistic Survey of India: Dravidian Languages
description:
The Linguistic Survey of India (LSI) was a survey of the languages of British India, conducted in the first several decades of the 20th century by the British Raj and directed by Irish linguist George A Grierson.

This particular map shows the languages and extent of the Dravidian family. In the original image, there appears to have been a coloring error, in which the colors in the legend do not match correctly with the regions on the map. We have restored what is, to our best knowledge, the correct correspondence.

On LSI maps of language families, such as this one, it is not always clear or consistent whether names refer to languages or subgroups. In our digitized versions, we have included the maximal language coding possible (i.e. if a name could refer to either a language or a subgroup, we include codes for both).
related:
This is a language family map. LL-MAP has digitized LSI maps for the following other language families, which you may want to overlay on this map for a more complete picture:
[Austro-Asiatic & Pronominalized Himalayan](ContributionTable#cldf:340620) |
[Dardic](ContributionTable#cldf:353501) |
[Indo-Aryan](ContributionTable#cldf:340282) |
[Siamese-Chinese](ContributionTable#cldf:355393) |
[Tibeto-Burman](ContributionTable#cldf:340668)

This map has a corresponding tree in MultiTree - see [Aryan (subtree of Indo-European): Grierson 1903](http://multitree.org/trees/Aryan%20(subtree%20of%20Indo-European)%3A%20Grierson%201903)

name: Sunda-Sahul-Wallacea: First Human Migration - LL-MAP
title: Sunda-Sahul-Wallacea Migration
description:
Migrations humaine à travers le sunda et le sahul. -60 à 50 000 années (Cagé). Human migration across Sunda to Sahul. 50,000-60,000 years ago.
		 
		Legend translation:  
		Terres emmergees lors du dernier maximum glaciaire. Land that emerged during the last glacial maximum. 
		Premieres migrations humaines -60 à 50 000 années. First human migration 50,000-60,000 years ago.

name: Linguistic Survey of India: District of Sonthal Parganas
description: The Linguistic Survey of India (LSI) was a survey of the languages of British India, conducted in the first several decades of the 20th century by the British Raj and directed by Irish linguist George A Grierson. This particular map shows the confluence of speech areas of Indo-Aryan languages within the district of Sonthal Parganas. (Today this district is part of Jharkhand state, bordering Bihar and West Bengal.)
related:
The languages on this map are Indo-Aryan - see [Linguistic Survey of India: Indo-Aryan Languages](ContributionTable#cldf:340282).

For a map of all dialects of Bengali (not just those in the Sonthal Parganas), see [Linguistic Survey of India: Bengali Dialects](ContributionTable#cldf:340694). This map has a corresponding tree in MultiTree - see [Aryan (subtree of Indo-European): Grierson 1903](http://multitree.org/trees/Aryan%20(subtree%20of%20Indo-European)%3A%20Grierson%201903)

name: Linguistic Survey of India: Munda Languages and Dialects
description:
The Linguistic Survey of India (LSI) was a survey of the languages of British India, conducted in the first several decades of the 20th century by the British Raj and directed by Irish linguist George A Grierson.

This particular map shows the speech varieties of the Munda group of the Austro-Asiatic family. Please note that you may have to zoom in from the default view in order to see many of the language labels.

Note for reading these maps: The original LSI maps do not indicate boundaries or areas for all languages/dialects. This is why some language/dialect names appear simply as labels, while others appear as areas. That is, these two categories of labels are not meaningfully different (i.e. they do not represent different subgroups or anything similar) unless the legend specifically indicates otherwise.
related:
Munda is a member of the Austro-Asiatic family, which is depicted in the LSI maps [](ContributionTable#cldf:341176)
[](ContributionTable#cldf:340620).

This map has a corresponding tree in MultiTree - see [Aryan (subtree of Indo-European): Grierson 1903](http://multitree.org/trees/Aryan%20(subtree%20of%20Indo-European)%3A%20Grierson%201903)

name: Linguistic Survey of India: Tai Languages
description:
The Linguistic Survey of India (LSI) was a survey of the languages of British India, conducted in the first several decades of the 20th century by the British Raj and directed by Irish linguist George A Grierson. This particular map shows the languages and extent of the Tai family in India.

On LSI maps, it is not always clear or consistent whether names refer to languages or subgroups. In our digitized versions, we have included the maximal language coding possible (i.e. if a name could refer to either a language or a subgroup, we include codes for both).

Note for reading these maps: The original LSI maps do not indicate boundaries or areas for all languages/dialects. This is why some language/dialect names appear simply as labels, while others appear as areas. That is, these two categories of labels are not meaningfully different (i.e. they do not represent different subgroups or anything similar) unless the legend specifically indicates otherwise.
related: Grierson's classifcation regards the Tai Languages as a subgroup of the [Siamese-Chinese](ContributionTable#cldf:355393) languages.

name: Language Atlas of China: Manchu-Tungus Languages
description:
Manchu-Tungus languages are spoken in China, Mongolia, and the former USSR; this map depicts the locations of those spoken in China. Use of these languages is declining - as of 1982, there were around 4.4 million ethnic Manchu-Tungus in China, only 46,000 of whom spoke Manchu-Tungus languages. Most of these speakers are bilingual in Chinese and their ethnic language; some also speak another neighboring minority language.

Regarding classification, the authors note that "some scholars outside China regard Xibo as a Manchu dialect, Oroqen as Evenki under a different name, and Hezhe as one of the sub-dialects ... of the Nanai language". They also note that the terms "Ewenki" and "Evenki" are not synonymous; the former refers to an ethnic group living in China, the latter to one living in the former USSR. The languages spoken by these two groups are different.

We have digitized a number of cities and place names to provide context for these language locations, which you can view by selecting them in the legend. The abbreviation A.C. stands for "'Autonomous County."
related:
To view the Manchu-Tungus languages of China in the context of neighboring families, see 
        [Language Atlas of China: Minority Languages in Northern China](ContributionTable#cldf:346160).

name: Bantu: Approximate Area of Bantu Nasal Harmony (Greenberg)
title: Approximate Area of Bantu Nasal Harmony
description: This work outlines the region of southern Africa where Bantu languages are spoken, and highlights the area where these languages make use of nasal harmony, a phenomenon in which some affixes have alternative forms to use when the root contains a nasal sound.  In the case of the Bantu languages, it can be observed with either a nasalized vowel or a consonant.  Greenberg uses this map to support his hypothesis regarding whether or not this may have been a trait inherited from Proto-Bantu or if it was introduced in another way (Greenberg).  Outside of Africa, this form of harmony is heard in many other languages, including Guaraní and Aguaruna.
source: Greenberg, Joseph Harold. 1951. "Vowel and nasal harmony in Bantu languages." Revue Congolaise 8.813–20.

name: Congo: Languages of Communities in the Epena District
title: Languages in the Epena district of Congo
description:
This map shows the distribution of languages in the Epena district in the Likouala Region of the People's Republic of the Congo, for the places and languages mentioned in Gardner (2006) that were possible to find coordinates for in the [National Geospatial intelligence Agency's online database ](http://geonames.nga.mil)
  The [Gardner (2006)](http://www.sil.org/silesr/2008/silesr2008-020.pdf) paper is based on two language surveys conducted in 1988 and 1989.
datasource:
Gardner, William L. 2006.[ Language Use in the Epena District of Northern Congo](http:///www.sil.org/silesr/2008/silesr2008-020.pdf). SIL Electronic Survey Report.
	    [The National Geospatial intelligence Agency's online coordinate database](http://geonames.nga.mil)
creator: Susanne Vejdemo

name: Kaliánan in Contemporary South America
title: Kaliánan in Contemporary South America
description: The areas of this map show where languages in the Kaliánan language group are spoken today. This original map was made by vectorizing data from the MultiTree language database and the Atlas of the World's Languages.
related: This folder (Contemporary South American Languages) contains other maps displaying linguistic subgroups in the region. Maps may be overlaid on each other for a more complete picture.

name: Chibcha-Misumalpan in Contemporary South America
title: Chibcha-Misumalpan in Contemporary South America
description: This map shows where languages in the Chibcha-Misumalpan language group were spoken ca. 2007. This original map was made by vectorizing data from the MultiTree language database and the Atlas of the World's Languages.
related: This folder (Contemporary South American Languages) contains other maps displaying linguistic subgroups in the region. The maps may be overlaid on each other for a more complete picture.

name: Páno-Takánan in Contemporary South America
title: Páno-Takánan in Contemporary South America
description: This map shows where languages in the Páno-Takánan language group were spoken in South America ca. 2007. This original map was made by vectorizing data from the MultiTree language database and the Atlas of the World's Languages.
related: This folder (Contemporary South American Languages) contains other maps displaying linguistic subgroups in the region. The maps may be overlaid on each other for a more complete picture.

name: Togo: Ginyanga-speaking communities
title: Ginyanga-speaking places in Togo
description:
This map shows the Ginyanga speaking communities mentioned in Diller and Jordan-Diller (2008), that were possible to find in the [National Geospatial intelligence Agency's online coordinate database ](http://geonames.nga.mil)
		The whole language area is described as follows: "The Anyanga people live in the Blitta division of the central province of Togo between the Togo
Mountains and the Mono River. Anyanga villages include: Agbandi, Diguina, Blitta-carrefour,
Doufouli, Pagala-village, Pagala-gare (for which Diguina-Konta is an alternate name), Anamagn&#233,
Doufouli-Akora, and a very small village named Diguina (II) between Pagala-village and Pagalagare [...] The villages previously listed are predominantly Anyanga with the
exception of Tchifama, which is now mostly Adel&#233-speaking. Pagala-gare and Blitta-carrefour also
have very mixed populations with many Ewe, Kotokoli, and Kabiy&#232 speakers.
The Anyanga are bordered by Kabiy&#232 villages to the east and south. There are also Kabiy&#232 villages
between Diguina and Pagala-village. To the west they are bound by Adel&#233 villages, and to the north
is a forest reserve. Kotokoli and Nawdm farming communities are interspersed throughout the area." (Diller and Jordan-Diller 2008)
		The Ginyanga language belongs to the Guang language family.
datasource:
Diller, Jason and Kari Jordan-Diller. 2008. [Ginyanga literacy development: a survey of attitudes and strategies](http://ww.sil.org/silesr/2008/silesr2008-020.pdf). SIL Electronic Survey Report.
	    [The National Geospatial intelligence Agency's online coordinate database](http://geonames.nga.mil)
creator: Linguist List (Susanne Vejdemo)

name: Languages of Tasmania (Schmidt and Capell)
title: Languages of Tasmania
description:
This map shows the classification of Tasmanian
languages pre-contact according to Wilhelm Schmidt and
Arthur Capell. Schmidt divides the island into two languages or groups (Eastern and Western Tasmanian) which may be further subdivided into a total of five languages or dialects. Capell supports the division into Eastern and Western Tasmanian, but is unsure of the language or dialect classification of the five subdivisions.
related:
[Languages of Tasmania
            (O'Grady and Jones)](ContributionTable#cldf:333023)
datasource: Schmidt, Wilhelm. 1952. Die Tasmanischen Sprachen: Quellen, Gruppierungen, Grammatik, Wörterbücher. Utrecht-Anvers: Spectrum. Capell, Arthur. 1968. What do we know of Tasmanian languages? Records of the Queen Victoria Museum, Launceston 30.1-7.

name: Chad: Zome Zirenkel-speaking villages in the Guera Province
title: Zirenkel-speaking places in Guera, Chad
description:
This map of the distribution of Zirenkel speaking places in the Guera Province in Chad, was created by combining data from the 
Johnson (2005) survey and coordinate information from the The National Geospatial intelligence Agency's online coordinate database.
datasource:
Johnson, Eric. 2005. [Étude Sociolinguistique De La Langue zirenkel Du Tchad](http://www.sil.org/silesr/2005/silesr2005-023.pdf). SIL Electronic Report
	    [The National Geospatial intelligence Agency's online coordinate database](http://geonames.nga.mil/ggmagaz/geonames4.asp)
creator: Linguist List (Susanne Vejdemo)

name: North America: Northwest Coastal Peoples (The Canadian Encyclopedia)-REPLACED_BY_GODDARD_MAP
title: Western Canada: Northwest Coastal People
description: This map shows the locations of some of the first peoples of western Canada along the Pacific Coast of Canada - languages which cross the border into Alaska indicate only their Canadian extent. For instance, Tlingit is spoken all the way down to the coast, but this is not shown on the map. These peoples arrived in the area around 10,000 years ago and formed several distinct groups with many unique languages; some estimate that there were nineteen languages or more present in the region, distributed across seventy or more nations. This map indicates language subgroupings.

name: Bougainville, 1873 - 1975: Ethnic Groups
title: Bougainville, 1873 - 1975: Ethnic Groups
description: This map depicts the ethnic groups of the Autonomous Region of Bougainville, Papua New Guinea from 1873 to 1975. Surveys were taken for the spans 1873-1907, 1908-1921, 1922-1946, 1947-1959, and 1960-1975, all of which are shown on this map. See pages 133-138, 142-146, 151-153, 159-161, and 169 respectively of the source text for further information regarding the individual ethnic groups.
related:
[Bougainville, 1873 - 1975: Languages](ContributionTable#cldf:333312)
[Ethnic Groups of New Britain: 1873-1975](ContributionTable#cldf:307250)
[Ethnic Groups of New Ireland: 1873-1975](ContributionTable#cldf:308779)

name: Sub-Saharan Africa: Western Mande Languages
title: Sub-Saharan Africa: Western Mande Languages
description: This map displays the locations where Western Mande languages are spoken throughout Sub-Saharan Africa. These languages, together with those of Eastern Mande, form a divergent branch of the Niger-Congo language family. This original map was made by vectorizing data from the [MultiTree](http://multitree.linguistlist.org/) language database and the Atlas of the World's Languages.
datasource: Wald, Benji. 2007. Sub-Saharan Africa. Atlas of the World's Languages, ed. by R. E. Asher and Christopher Moseley, 301. Oxford: Routledge. [MultiTree: Niger Congo: Composite](ContributionTable#cldf-multitree:Niger-Congo%3A%20Composite)

name: South-East Asia: Austric Dispersal Theory
title: Austric Dispersal
description:
This map illustrates the dispersal of the two branches of the Austric
theory. The Austronesians moved through China along the Yangtze Jiang
River and down the east coast of China between 10,000 and 6,000 BP. The
Austroasiatic group moved in three different directions: west, south, and
southeast.
The encircled numbers denote progressively later stages in the dispersal.
datasource: [Paul Jen-kuei Li. 2001. The Dispersal of the Formosan Aborigines in Taiwan. Language and Linguistics 2.1:271-278](http://www.ling.sinica.edu.tw/eip/FILES/journal/2007.3.9.13169497.1198156.pdf)

name: Austronesian Area: Austronesian Language Families
title: Austronesian Language Zones
description:
This map illustrates the distribution of the Austronesian language family and major subgroupings (Bellwood).
		 
		Note: This map contains data on both sides of the 180th Parallel. Because of constraints on the base map, maps like this will not automatically 
zoom properly, and part of the data (specifically the line to the east) does not show up. This creates serious display problems, and we recommend that viewers consult
the original map before using this LLMAP map.
source: [Bellword, Peter.  2000.  Formosan Prehistory and Austronesian Dispersal.  Electronic Cultural Atlas Initiative (ECAI)](http://ecai.org)

name: Bolivia: Locations of Original Languages (Public Content)
title: Locations of Original Languages of Bolivia
description: This map illustrates the approximate locations of the original and early peoples and languages in Bolivia.
source: Wikimedia Commons: [Locations of Original Languages of Bolivia](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Pueblos_originarios_de_Bolivia.png)

name: North Asia: Paleoasiatic and other North Asiatic languages (TITUS)
title: Paleoasiatic and other North Asiatic Languages
description: This map depicts the languages of North Asia. Moving roughly from north to south in the western part of the map, the Uralic languages are divided into Samoyedic, Ob-Ugric, Turkic, and Mongolian. Directly to the east and north are Tungusic languages, while Paleoasiatic languages are located to the far north and east.
datasource: H. Glück (ed.), Metzler Lexikon Sprache, Stuttgart / Weimar: Metzler 1993, p. 659.
license: Jost Gippert, Frankfurt a/M 1999-2003. This server provides teaching materials concerning Indo-European and Non-Indo-European languages. Those materials that can be downloaded via http can be used freely for teaching purposes, provided that they are quoted as sources and the name(s) of the editor(s) and the date of last changes are indicated. No parts of this document may be republished in any form without prior permission by the copyright holder.

name: Isogloss map for intervowel -d- elision, except for -ado suffixes, in Iberian Peninsula Spanish, according to ALPI.
description:
Intervowel -d- elision happens in all of the peninsula for certain contexts, but it clearly increases from north to south.
The words registered in the ALPI surveys that have been used in this map are: 
cazador (ALPI map 39)
dedo (ALPI map 63)
desnudo (ALPI map 66)
deudas (ALPI map 67)
source: Jota, Martin. January 2007. Isogloss map for intervowel -d- elision, except for -ado suffixes, in Iberian Peninsula Spanish, according to ALPI, October 2011. Online:   [http://www.jotamartin.byethost33.com/alpi_dinter_e.php.](http://www.jotamartin.byethost33.com/alpi_dinter_e.php)
datasource: Heap, David. 2003. Linguistics Atlas of the Iberian Peninsula. Ontario: University of Western Ontario. Online: [http://westernlinguistics.ca/alpi/.](http://westernlinguistics.ca/alpi/)
license: The reproduction and use of the data collected in these pages is explicitly authorised, exclusively for research or teaching purposes, provided this copyright notice is included in any publication, the source (www.alpi.ca) is always cited, and provided that there is no charge for the data beyond the normal price of the physical medium (if applicable). All sales, marketing or other for-profit uses of these data are specifically forbidden.

name: Australian Languages
Isogloss map for final -d elision, in Iberian Peninsula Spanish, according to ALPI
description:
This map is complex, as in many of the surveyed points there is hesitation about pronouncing the final -d, generally voiceless (as the Castilian z) and most of the times relaxed, or not pronouncing anything. It's better to speak of a hesitation area in the Duero valley and upper Ebro, while in the rest of the peninsula the usual option is not pronouncing anything.

The only word registered in the ALPI surveys that has been used in this map is verdad.
source: Jota, Martin. January 2007. Isogloss map for final -d elision, in Iberian Peninsula Spanish, according to ALPI, September 2011. Online:  [http://www.jotamartin.byethost33.com/alpi0_e.php.](http://www.jotamartin.byethost33.com/alpi_dfinal_e.php)
datasource: Heap, David. 2003. Linguistics Atlas of the Iberian Peninsula. Ontario: University of Western Ontario. Online: [http://westernlinguistics.ca/alpi/.](http://westernlinguistics.ca/alpi/)
license: The reproduction and use of the data collected in these pages is explicitly authorised, exclusively for research or teaching purposes, provided this copyright notice is included in any publication, the source (www.alpi.ca) is always cited, and provided that there is no charge for the data beyond the normal price of the physical medium (if applicable). All sales, marketing or other for-profit uses of these data are specifically forbidden.
creator: Martin Jota

name: Lands Granted to the Vikings byThe Carolingians in Northern France (10th Century)
title: The Carolingian Empire in Northern France
description: This map shows an area of the Carolingian empire in Northern France, along the English Channel. The land granted by the Carolingians at different points in time from the years 911 to 933 are displayed, as well as sites of archaeological finds and sites with Scandinavian place-names.
related: The Vikings As Traders Viking Raids

name: Language Atlas of China: Miao-Yao Languages
description: This map illustrates the reach of various Miao-Yao (Hmong-Mien) languages within the borders of the People's Republic of China, spoken by people of Miao, Yao, and She nationalities. Although they are not separately displayed on the map itself, each of these languages also spans several distinct dialects.

name: Mura-Matanawían in Contemporary South America
title: Mura-Matanawían in Contemporary South America
description: This map shows where languages in the Mura-Matanawían language group were spoken ca. 2007. This original map was made by vectorizing data from the MultiTree language database and the Atlas of the World's Languages.
related: This folder (Contemporary South American Languages) contains other maps displaying linguistic subgroups in the region. The maps may be overlaid on each other for a more complete picture.
datasource:
kaufman2007[83-93]
        Macro-Warpean cluster: Campbell 1997. [MultiTree: A Digital Library of Language Relationships](http://multitree.org/trees/Macro-Warpean%20cluster%3A%20Campbell%201997)

name: The Vikings As Traders
description: In the Viking Age, Scandinavia was involved in extensive trading with Europe, Russia and Asia. Raw materials were exported in exchange for goods that were luxuries to the Vikings, such as honey, silk, wine, pottery and more. This map shows the trade routes as well as which specific goods were imported and exported from certain areas. Also included are linguistic groups of the areas that were doing the trading.

name: North America: Caddoan: Contemporary
title: Caddoan in Contemporary North America
description: The polygons and points represent concentrations of first-language speakers of Caddoan languages. Polygons represent land or areas primarily occupied by first-language speakers whereas points show communities with varying numbers of speakers. This original map was made by vectorizing data from the MultiTree language database and the Atlas of the World's Languages.
related: This folder (North America: Contemporary) contains other maps showing contemporary linguistic subgroups.  The maps may be overlaid on each other for a more complete picture.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: FOREHEAD
title: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: FOREHEAD
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for qauq, B stands for qauraq, and C stands for cung'uq, D stands for tatek, and E stands for tautek. For the Yup’ik item—Forehead--Jacobson points out that the various Yup’ik words for ‘forehead’ are related to the meanings of the cognates in other Eskimo languages. He also notes that the distribution of this Yup’ik item is unusual because an uncommon form is shared by Hooper Bay- Chevak and the upper Kuskokwim. The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.
Non-Yup’ik Languages Notation
North Alaskan Inupiaq A
Seward Peninsula Inupiaq A
Sirenikski A
(Central) Siberian Yupik A
Naukanski Yupik A
Konlag Alutiiq D
Chugach Alutiiq D

name: Linguistic Survey of India: Pashto and Ormuri Languages
description:
The Linguistic Survey of India (LSI) was a survey of the languages of British India, conducted in the first several decades of the 20th century by the British Raj and directed by Irish linguist George A Grierson.

This particular map shows the extent of the Pashto and Ormuri languages.
related:
Pashto  is an Iranian language, which Grierson classified as a sister branch to the Indo-Aryan; thus, for comparison you may be interested in [](ContributionTable#cldf:340282)
[](ContributionTable#cldf:353161).

This map has a corresponding tree in MultiTree - see [Aryan (subtree of Indo-European): Grierson 1903](http://multitree.org/trees/Aryan%20(subtree%20of%20Indo-European)%3A%20Grierson%201903)

name: Sri Lanka: Moors Tamil Speaking Enclaves (Breton)
title: Sri Lanka: Moors Tamil Speaking Enclaves
description:
'Moors Tamil' refers to the language spoken by the Arab Moors that settled in Sri Lanka. According to [Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sri_Lankan_Moors#Languages), there is no official name for this specific dialect, so it is generally referred to as 'Tamil.' This dialect has been heavily influenced by Arabic as it meshed with a number of indigenous Sri Lankan languages, and also those languages of immigrants from mainland India. 
Notes on reading this map:
This map is designed to be overlaid onto other maps of Sri Lanka, in order to gain a more in depth view of the languages spoken on the island.

related: This folder (North America: Contemporary) contains other maps showing contemporary linguistic subgroups.  The maps may be overlaid on each other for a more complete picture.

name: North America: Uto-Aztecan: Contemporary
title: Uto-Aztecan in Contemporary North America
description: The polygons and points represent concentrations of first-language speakers of Uto-Aztecan languages. Polygons represent land or areas primarily occupied by first-language speakers whereas points show communities with varying numbers of speakers. This original map was made by vectorizing data from the MultiTree language database and the Atlas of the World's Languages.
related: This folder (North America: Contemporary) contains other maps showing contemporary linguistic subgroups.  The maps may be overlaid on each other for a more complete picture. The northern distribution of Uto-Aztecan languages originally shown in the Northern North America: Contemporary map has been included here for completeness.

name: West Caucasus: Abkhaz-Adyghe Ethnic Groups and Languages in the 1830's
title: Abkhaz-Adyghe Ethnic Groups and Languages in the 1830's
description: This map depicts the Abkhaz-Adyghe Ethnic and Linguistic Groups in southwest Russia and Georgia as they were in the 1830's. The map is divided broadly into three groups - Adyghe, Ubykh, and Abkhaz Abaza and also includes layers depicting residential areas and pasture land. This map has been modified from it's original in the Atlas of the Caucasian languages, and historical cities in this region have also been added. Abkhaz-Abaza: Abkhaz, Sadskzo Divisions, the Ethnic groups named Ahibga, Art, Baga, Goch', Tsanda, and Tsvykdzhi are listed as text on the original map and are represented here as text labels representing an approximate geographical location; the same is the case for the Adyghe, Western Circassian Dividison in the Adyghe (dialect unspecified) regions for the following ethnic groups: Bzhedugh, Cherchenay,Khegaki, Natekuay, X'imisch. It should also be noted that the populated places on this map are the places indicated in the original map and do not represent an exhaustive list of populated places for this region.
source:
Коряков Ю. Б. Атлас кавказских языков / РАН. Ин-т языкознания. — Москва: Пилигрим, 2006. — 76 с.: карты.

creator: [Ljuba Veselinova](http://www.ling.su.se/staff/ljuba/), [Geographic Information Systems in Linguistics (GISLI), Stockholm University](http://www2.ling.su.se/eng/)

name: West Caucasus: Adyghe, Kabardino-Circassian, and Abaza Languages - needs fixing
title: The Adyghe, Kabardino-Circassian, and Abaza Languages
description: This map depicts Adyghe, Kabardino-Circassian, and Abaza Languages in southwest Russia and Georgia. In addition to the Kabardian language family, there is also a layer of Kabardian multilingual areas. The map amalgamates two maps in the Atlas of the Caucasian languages; it should also be noted that the populated places on this map are only places indicated in the original maps and do not represent an exhaustive list of populated places for this region.

name: Ethnic Groups of New Ireland: 1873-1975
description: This map displays the locations of ethnic groups on New Ireland, a province of Papua New Guinea. The data spans the years 1873-1975 and is divided into five distinct time periods. Each period is represented with different color text and can be turned on and off via the "Active Layers" tab. The original series of maps combined information from different sources, and as a result certain groups appear under multiple names. Although the term "ethnic groups" is used, Wassmann notes that most terms refer to locations or language names. The group names in the 1873-1907 data set, with Butam as the sole exception, are all taken from island names (for smaller islands) or region names (for the main island). During the period of 1947-1959, no new ethnic group names were mentioned.
related: Additional maps from this source include Languages of New Britain: 1873-1975, Ethnic Groups of New Britain: 1873-1975, and Languages of New Ireland: 1873-1975.

name: The Vikings in Brittany
description: In Brittany, the Celtic population had to fight hard and frequently in order to remain independent from the nearby Carolingian empire. Additionally, Viking raids came from the same route over and over again between 819 and 914. After nearly a century of attacks, in 914, the Vikings were able to take control of the region; Viking control lasted until 939.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: FISH EGG, ROE
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for meluk, B stands for imlauk, C stands for cuak, D stands for cilluvak, and E stands for cin'aq. For the Yup’ik item—Fish egg, roe—Jacobson notes that meluk may be the nominal counterpart of melug- ‘to suck’. Cognates of imlauk means ‘fetus of an animal (especially a seal)’ in other Eskimo languages, and cilluvak and cuak may be cognates that found in various outlying areas of Yup’ik and in other Eskimo. He also points out that cin'aqmeans ‘aged fish eggs’ in Nunivak only and ‘aged fish’ in Yukon, Hooper Bay- Chevak, and Lake Iliamna (and in Alutiiq). The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: FISH SCALE
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for kapeciq, kapciq, and B stands for qelta. For the Yup’ik item—Fish scaleJacobson notes that in all Yupik languages and in Sirenikski qelta (and cognates) is used. It means ‘bark, peeling’ in Alutiiq and is a second meaning in Yup’ik. A cognate of kapeciq/ kapciq is the Inupiaq word for ‘scale’, but it is not a loan word from Inupiaq. kapeciq is from proto-Eskimo and has disappeared except in the north where Inupiaq reinforcement may have play a role. name: Eskimo Interethnic Contacts: Bering Strait & Alaska Area
description: This map illustrates interethnic contact in the Bering Strait and Alaska area and the languages spoken there. Fifteen percent of Alaska is Native, of which 36,000 are of Eskimo descent. The majority of Alaska Natives speak English. According to van der Voort, there are many instances where Eskimos created grammatically reduced versions of their languages in order to communicate with monolingual speakers of other languages, and some developed into pidgins that served as a lingua franca. There is only limited information on such languages.
source: van der Voort, Hein. 1996. Eskimo Interethnic Contacts: Bering Strait & Alaska Area. In Atlas of Languages of Intercultural Communication in the Pacific, Asia, and the Americas. II.2. Stephen Wurm, Peter Mühlhäusler and Darrell Tryon (eds). Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.

name: National Ethnic Makeup - People of Russia
description: This map displays the contemporary distribution of ethnic groups in Russia. It includes a set of points for which there was no corresponding item in the original map's legend. This set is designated here as "Unknown Ethnic Group". The map comes from a four volume set of Russian cartographic data from geology to history.
source: 2004. Natsionalnyi atlas Rossii v Chetyrekh. Vol 3. Moscow: Federalnaia sluzhba geodezii i kartografii Rossii.

name: A New Hypothesis of Austronesian Expansion and Cultural Contact
title: A New Hypothesis of Austronesian Expansion and Cultural Contact
description:
Reflected upon this map is a new hypothesis of Austronesian expansion, based upon research in linguistics, archaeology and human genetics.  The majority of current studies agree that Taiwanese peoples are related both genetically and linguistically to Austronesians now living in southeast Asia and the Pacific, and many sources agree that they probably arrived on the island from mainland China around 6000 years ago.  From this point, however, linguistic and genetic hypotheses have diverged: historical linguists and archaeologists have so far supported a model in which Austronesians migrated south through the Philippines to what is now Indonesia, spreading east and west from there.  Geneticists, however, have found that many Austronesian populations are more closely related to their mainland Asian ancestors than they are to the Taiwanese, in effect making the Taiwan aboriginal peoples and the Austronesians parallel branches from the same tree. 
Also included here are several genetic and archaeological hypotheses of cultural contact and migration, including Blench's (2010) proposal of contact with the Indian subcontinent and Delfin et al.'s (2010) genetic relations with several Australian aboriginal groups.   
Rather than viewing Austronesian expansion as a series of straightforward migrations, it seems more and more necessary to delve more deeply into the history and culture of the peoples and the area in order to better reconstruct their history.  As further research is undertaken, more of these details will come to light, allowing interdisciplinary scholars to continue improving on what seems to be a solid foundational understanding of the region and its linguistic and genetic history.

name: Austronesian Migration (Cribb)
title: Austronesian Migrations
description: Shown here are migration routes for Austronesian-language speakers which resulted in the settlement of permanent populations.  Each path has been labeled according to the estimated date that it was taken, as determined through linguistic, archaeological and ecological research.  According to Cribb, the first Austronesians arrived in Taiwan around 4500 BC and from there progressed south before spreading outward (Cribb 2010).  This hypothesis differs from the one currently supported by genetic research, as shown in maps such as those listed in Other Resources below.
source: Cribb, Robert. 2010. Austronesian migrations. Digital Atlas of Indonesian History. Nias Press.
related:
[Southeast Asia: Proposed Migrations based on Genetic Analysis (HUGO Pan-Asian SNP Consortium)](ContributionTable#cldf:109891)
[Philippines: Philippine Settlement, Migration and Contact](ContributionTable#cldf:110011)

name: The Express Train to Polynesia Model (Gray and Jordan)
title: The Express Train to Polynesia Model
description: This map is a graphical representation of the "Express Train" model of Austronesian migration, a popular hypothesis based on archaeological and linguistic research.  In their article, Gray and Jordan (2000) explain how they made use of a tree model, most commonly used in biology, to first create a language family tree.  Then, using statistical analysis, they analyzed the likelihood of their proposed sequence of events (in this case, the migration patterns) occurring.  Each of the circles on this map represents one of the stations compared against the language family tree.  They found that the hypothesized routes fit the language tree exceptionally well, and the statistical analysis showed that, "that the express-train character-state tree fits the language tree with significantly fewer steps than would occur by chance," (Gray and Jordan 2000: 1053).
source: [Gray, Russell D. and Fiona M. Jordan. 2000. Language trees support the express-train sequence of Austronesian expansion. Nature 405. 1052-1055.](http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v405/n6790/full/4051052a0.html)

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: FORGETTING IT
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for avaurluku, B stands for nalluyagulluku, and C stands for nalluqerluku, D stands for unimluku, and E stands for kic'iluku. For the Yup’ik item— Forgetting it--Jacobson notes that the verb basenalluyagute- literally ‘to come to a state of not knowing’ is used in everywhere except Norton Sound Unaliq. avaur- ‘to forget’ is represented in Naukanski to the north, in Chugach Alutiiq to the south and in the peripheral Yup’ik dialects. therefore, Jacobson suggests that it may be the original Yup’ik word, and nalluyagute- (and nalluqar- ‘to suddenly not know’) may be a GCY innovation that spread to Koniag Alutiiq. unime- is related to unite- ‘to leave behind’ and kic'i- ‘to have something sink on one’, and both of which are localism according to Jacobson. The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: HEAD
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for nasquq, B stands for qamiquq, C stands for uqsuq, and D stands for iingaraq. For the Yup’ik item—Head--Jacobson notes that nasquq is the northern Yup’ik word and has cognates in other Eskimo. qamiquq and uqsuq are found only in Yup’ik. uqsuq is used for ‘head’ in the upriver/far inland Yup’ik areas but occurs only as ‘aged fish head’ in Hooper Bay- Chevak and Norton Sound. It is also used throughout the southern part of Yup’ik in uqsuqaq PINTAIL DUCK. He also suggests that iingaraq (may from ii ‘eye’) on Nunivak is mainly used for ‘fish head’ but could also refer to ‘human or animal head’. The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: HEART
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for unguvan, and B stands for ircaquq. For the Yup’ik item—Heart--Jacobson discusses the atypical distribution of the two Yup’ik words for ‘heart’. He notes that ircaquq is used in the same area as various body part innovations from core GCY and has cognates outside Yup’ik. The peripheral GCY word unguvan, literally ‘device for living’, “is a descriptive term formed with an instrumental postbase” according to Jacobson. The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: HORSE
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for tunturpak, B stands for luussitaq, C stands for luussatiq, D stands for uassaq, horse-aq, and E stands for kuuniq. For the Yup’ik item—Horse—Jacobson notes the both Russian loan words: kuuniq from kon’ and luussitaq from lо́shad’, and their isogloss follows a traditional north vs. south patter. tunturpak, literally means ‘big moose’, is used in Norton Sound Unaliq, and the area around Bethel uses the Yup’icized English word. He also mentions that the variant luussatiq (from Russian Mission) is closer to the Russian original, lо́shad’ than the common form luussitaq because Russian mission was the center of Russian influence. name: Northern Asia: North Caucasian Languages
title: Northern Asia: North Caucasian Languages
description: This map displays the locations where North Caucasian languages are spoken throughout Northern Asia. While the area inhabited by speakers  is comparable to those of the South Caucasian languages, there are far more languages in this language group.  This original map was made by vectorizing data from the [MultiTree](http://multitree.linguistlist.org/) language database and the Atlas of the World's Languages.

name: Slav settlement of the Balkans
title: Slav settlement of the Balkans in the seventh and eighth centuries
description: Taking information from written records and archeological evidence (although minimal), this map demonstrates the approximate Slav settlement patterns across the Balkan region. The various Slavic group names on this map illustrate the approximate locations in the sevent and eighth centuries. Their settlement appears to be inconsistent over the area which is thought to be due to the mountainous terrains.

name: Taiwan: Ethnic Groups (Melton et al.)
title: Taiwan Ethnic Groups
description: This map gives approximate geographic boundaries for eight aboriginal groups in Taiwan.
source: [Melton, Terry, Stephanie Clifford, Jeremy Martinson, Mark Batzer and Mark Stoneking.  1998.  Genetic Evidence for the Proto-Austronesian Homeland in Asia: mtDNA and Nuclear DNA Variation in Taiwanese Aboriginal Tribes. American Journal of Human Genetics. 1807-1823.](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1377653/pdf/9837834.pdf)

name: The Philippines: The Numerically Most Important Languages
title: The Philippines: The Numerically Most Important Languages
description:
This map shows the 'Major Indigenous Languages' of the Philippines at the time of contact, as determined by number of speakers. All the languages included have more than 1 million speakers, and are considered 'Lingua Franca's' in the different regions of the country. The Philippines linguistic make up includes approximately 150 different languages (Irvine and Appleyard 2007).
This original map was made by vectorizing data from the MultiTree language database and the Atlas of the World's Languages.
related: This map is part of a mapping project detailing the languages of the Australian and Austronesian language families. (Information forthcoming). The maps may be overlaid on each other for a more complete picture.
datasource: Irvine, A. K and David Appleyard. 2007. "Australasia and the South Pacific". In R. E. Asher & Christopher Moseley (eds.). Atlas of the World’s Languages. Oxford: Routledge. [MultiTree: Austronesian: Composite 2011](ContributionTable#cldf-multitree:Austronesian%3A%20Composite)

name: Northern Asia: Ket
title: Northern Asia: Ket
description: This map displays the locations where Ket is spoken throughout Northern Asia. This language, today a language isolate, is considered to be one of the last representatives of the Yenisei language family, its speakers inhabiting a small area of central Russia.  This original map was made by vectorizing data from the [MultiTree](http://multitree.linguistlist.org/) language database and the Atlas of the World's Languages.

name: Northern Asia: Nivkh
title: Northern Asia: Nivkh
description: This map displays the locations where Nivkh is spoken throughout Northern Asia. This language, also called 'Gilyak', is considered to be a language isolate, its speakers inhabiting only a few small areas in eastern Russia.  This original map was made by vectorizing data from the [MultiTree](http://multitree.linguistlist.org/) language database and the Atlas of the World's Languages.

name: Southeast Asia: Miao (Language Atlas of the Pacific)
description: This map is an LL-MAP amalgamation of Miao (Meo) language polygons from both the Mainland S.E. Asia (N) and Hainan map (©ECAI Digital Language Atlas of the Pacific Area) and The Dialects of the Miao Language map (Language Atlas of China) to create a map showing all the Miao/Meo Language polygons in the entire SE Asia region.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: HUMPBACK SALMON
title: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: HUMPBACK SALMON
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for terteq, B stands for cuqpeq, C stands for amaqsuq, D stands for amaqsuk (pronounced amaqsug), and E stands for amaqaayak. For the Yup’ik item—Humpback salmon—Jacobson notes that amaqsuq/ amaqsuk and amaqaayak refer to the salmons species’ hump (amaq). He suggests that the use of amaqsuq/ amaqsuk only in the area far from the borders with other Eskimos (the Nelson Is. area in Yup’ik and Nunivak) is unusual. Cuqpeq may relate to cuqlur- ‘bent out of shape’ and cuqir- ‘being bent’ refers the fish’s hump. terteq’s etymology is unknown. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: ICE
title: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: ICE
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for ciku, and B stands for qenu. For the Yup’ik item—Ice—Jacobson notes that qenu and ciku are used both outside and in some areas inside Yup’ik. Genu is ‘fragile ice on the water (either slush ice or a thin layer)’. qenu appears in the derivative form qenuirun ‘net-like scoop for removing ice fragments from a water hole’ in the places where only ciku is used. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: "JACKRABBIT," ARCTIC HARE
title: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: "JACKRABBIT", ARCTIC HARE
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for qayuqeggliq, B stands for ugasek, and C stands for negilirkaq. For the Yup’ik item—"Jackrabbit", arctic hare--Jacobson notes that qayuqeggliq literally means ‘good for soup’, and “the Canineq localism negilirkaq means ‘raw material for a parka ruff’”. He suggests that ugasek is an unusual word and may relate to uatek ‘haunches.’ The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.
Non-Yup’ik Languages Notation
North Alaskan Inupiaq X
Seward Peninsula Inupiaq X
Sirenikski *
(Central) Siberian Yupik *
Naukanski Yupik *
Konlag Alutiiq *
Chugach Alutiiq *

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: LAMP, LIGHT
title: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: LAMP, LIGHT
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for naniq, B stands for kenurraq, and C stands for kuman. For the Yup’ik item—Lamp, light—Jacobson notes that naniq is used in the northern part of Yup’ik similar to Eskimo languages to the north, and kenurraq is mostly used in the southern part with a cognate found to the north in Naukanski meaning ‘candle’. Kenurraq and kuman are based on eke- ‘to burn’, and kuman is derived from kuma- ‘to be lit’ and –n ‘instrument’, according to the author. He suggests that Kuman occurring in Upper Kuskokwim, Nunivak, and the Egegik area supports the E.W. Nelson version of the Aglurmiut hypothesis. Finally he notes that “the Chugach Alutiiq form is a direct nominalization of kuma-" and speculates that this is not cognate to kuman. The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.
Non-Yup’ik Languages Notation
North Alaskan Inupiaq A
Seward Peninsula Inupiaq A
Sirenikski A
(Central) Siberian Yupik A
Naukanski Yupik B/A
Konlag Alutiiq A
Chugach Alutiiq C

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: MAQIVIK (pronunciation)
title: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: MAQIVIK (PRONUNCIATION)
description: This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for pronounced with [v], B stands for pronounced with [w]. For the Yup’ik item—Maqivik (pronunciation)—Jacobson discusses the item assessing whether"v which is ungerminated between full vowels (i.e. not e) at a morpheme boundary" pronounces as [v] or [w]. According to the map, the author points out that “peripheral GCY (with some exceptions) uses [v] and core GCY uses [w]”. Also, he notes that in Hooper Bay- Chevak v always is [v] and never [w]. One can compare a similar situation regarding to y and s at HEY YOU WHAT ARE YOU DOING?

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: MILK
title: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: MILK
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for amngaq, B stands for muluk'uuq, and C stands for malak'uuq. For the Yup’ik item—Milk—Jacobson addresses the question concerning the word for ‘canned milk’, ‘milk in a carton’, etc. According to the author, a Russian loan word is used except in Norton Sound Unaliq which uses amngaq ‘breast milk’. Malak'uuq, used only in Nunivak, Nelson Is, and Stebbins, is a more common Russian pronunciation from the Russian source word molokо́ and muluk'uuq has less Russian sounding. He suggests that the Russians who introduced ‘milk’ might have spoken minority dialect of Russian. Finally, he points out that in several areas there is milek from English and milek’uuq from a blend of English and Russian. The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.
Non-Yup’ik Languages Notation
North Alaskan Inupiaq *
Seward Peninsula Inupiaq *
Sirenikski *
(Central) Siberian Yupik *
Naukanski Yupik *
Konlag Alutiiq B
Chugach Alutiiq B

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: (STRAIGHT) KNIFE
title: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: (STRAIGHT) KNIFE
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for cavik, B stands for caviggaq, C stands for uluaq, D stands for nuussiq, and E stands for luussiq. For the Yup’ik item—(Straight) knife—Jacobson notes that the Russian loan word nuussiq and “semi-predicable Nunivak variant” luussiq has become the standard word for this type of knife in many areas, excluding cavik meaning ‘metal’ or ‘iron’ only. Caviggaq, literally ‘small cavik’, is ‘knife’ in most of the rest Yup’ik. Uluaq is used for “the straight or men’s style knife and semi-lunar or woman’s style knife” in the Canineq area. The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.

Seward Peninsula Inupiaq A
Sirenikski B

Naukanski Yupik A

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: OLDER SISTER
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for al'qaq, B stands for alqaq, C stands for alleqaq, and D stands for al'aq. For the Yup’ik item—Older sister—Jacobson discusses the variety forms of Yup’ik word for ‘older sister’. H states that *aleqaq must have been the original Yup’ik form comparing with Inupiaq, and the “hatted” e has been deleted to give al'qaq and therefore, alqaq, in and beyond areas “where a voiced fricative cannot precede a stop". One can compare this to (IT) WILL SPILL. Also, he suggests that alleqaq in Norton Sound Unaliq may be “from a reinsertion of this ‘hatted’ e but with l kept voiceless.” Finally, he points out that “al’a is a widespread casual or endearing form of the basic word” but may have replaced alqaq to a degree in the Lake Iliamna area. The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.
Non-Yup’ik Languages Notation
North Alaskan Inupiaq A
Seward Peninsula Inupiaq X
Sirenikski X
(Central) Siberian Yupik X
Naukanski Yupik X
Konlag Alutiiq A=B
Chugach Alutiiq A

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: (IN THE EXTENDED AREA) OUT THERE
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for qiini and B stands for qagaani. For the Yup’ik item—(In the extended area) out there—Jacobson discusses the item that addresses the formation of adverbs from the three demonstrative pronouns agna ‘that across there (extended)’, pagna ‘that up there (extended)’, and qagna ‘that out there (extended)’. The standard pattern for this adverb formation is that “the final segment na of the pronoun is replaced with ani (and similarly for case other than the localis), giving first *agani,*pagani, and *qagani (compare amani ‘over there (obscured)’ and then by velar-dropping and vowel-raising these become iini ‘across there’, piini ‘up there’, and qiini ‘out there’. While Norton Sound, Nunivak and the area where the Yukon and Kuskokwim are close together and follow this standard pattern, all the rest of Yup’ik avoid such vowel-raising and insert an extra a instead to give agaani, pagaani, and qagaani. The author notes that the vowel-raising (not the velar-dropping) is “objectionable,” and therefore, from the demonstrative pronoun ugna ‘that toward exist (restrict)’, one gets the adverb *ugani and hence uani ‘toward exit’. The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.
Non-Yup’ik Languages Notation
North Alaskan Inupiaq *
Seward Peninsula Inupiaq *
Sirenikski *
(Central) Siberian Yupik *
Naukanski Yupik *
Konlag Alutiiq B
Chugach Alutiiq B

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: PANTS
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for qerrulliik and B stands for ulruk. For the Yup’ik item—Pants—Jacobson notes the word for ‘pants’ which is "shibboleth" to distinguish Bristol Bay and Kuskokwim, and other examples are BOAT, “RABBIT”, COAT, and (BEING) SICK. Due to the use of cognates of qerrulliik in Eskimo languages to the north of Yup’ik and of ulruk in Alutiiq, the pattern can be north vs. south with the division line far to the south (COOKING is another example). FISHHOOK is a case of the division line in the middle. The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.
Non-Yup’ik Languages Notation
North Alaskan Inupiaq A
Seward Peninsula Inupiaq A
Sirenikski *
(Central) Siberian Yupik A
Naukanski Yupik A
Konlag Alutiiq B
Chugach Alutiiq B

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: PLUCKING IT
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for eritarlulku, B stands for neritarluku, C stands for erritarluku, and D stands for meqtarluku. For the Yup’ik item—Plucking it—Jacobson notes the north vs. south pattern illustrated by the distribution of meqtarluku and erritarluku (and variants). Meqtar- comes from meqte- ‘to cause to shed fur or feathers’, and erritarluku is a variant of eritarlulku which is predictable for Egegik. Finally, as the author points out, neritarluku in Hooper bay is a development similar to what gives nenglarluni in Hooper Bay- Checak for LAUGHING as opposed to englarluni/ngel’arluni elsewhere.” The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.

Seward Peninsula Inupiaq A
Sirenikski A
(Central) Siberian Yupik A

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: CUTTING FISH FOR DRYING
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for cegluni, B stands for segluni, C stands for essgiluni, and D stands for ulligciluni. For the Yup’ik item—Cutting fish for drying--Jacobson notes that the distribution of the variants cegluni/ segluni/ essgiluni is predictable and can be found in TEA & SUGAR, and the others. Ulligciluni is a localism from Bethel area and is not related to ullirciluni ‘to split the belly.’ He also points out that ceg- and seg- are “agentive” verb base, and esseg- (in Nunivak) and ulligte- are “patientive.” The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.

Seward Peninsula Inupiaq *
Sirenikski *
(Central) Siberian Yupik *
Naukanski Yupik *
Konlag Alutiiq B

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: (HE IS) CRYING
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for qiaguq, B stands for qeyauq, and C stands for qesauq. For the Yup’ik item—(He is) crying--Jacobson discusses the deletion of the intervocalic y/s in core GCY. He notes that qesauq and qeyaluni are used in Nunivak and Golovin when speakers keepy/s. qesauq ( pronounced as qessaur) is due to germination, qeyaluni not. The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.
