name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: I DON'T LOVE HIM
description: This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for kenékenrítaqa, B stands for kénkenrítaqa, and C stands for kénkénritáqa. For the Yup’ik item—I don't love him—Jacobson discusses the prosody difference among the two subdialects of the Norton Sound dialect and the rest of Yup’ik. He notes that “neither the Kotlik nor Unaliq subdialects of Norton Sound retract stress from an open syllable (ri in ken(e)kenritaqa) to a preceding closed syllable, which is unlike the rest of Yup’ik. According to the author, Unaliq “retains stressed e in an open syllable (the second e in kenékenritaqa), and then closes the syllable by germinating the following consonant” which is unlike Kotlik and the rest of Yup’ik.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: IT IS UP ABOVE THERE
description: This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for pikani etuq, B stands for pikanetuq, and C stands for pika'antuq. For the Yup’ik item—It is up above there--Jacobson notes that this item “assesses the degree to which the largely obsolete verb base ete- ‘to be’ forms a contraction with the localis case, particularly the demonstrative adverbs such as pikani ‘up above there.’" He also discusses that the uncontracted two-word form is used only in Nunivak, and elsewhere contraction gives pikanetuq that goes one step further into pika'antuq. It is a process of deletion of a certain vowel that creates a long and unrhythmical vowel which does not cause germination. its process is similar to the case (HE) KEEPS BEING SAD. Finally the author points out the last step is "obligatory (with demonstrative adverbs) except in outlying dialect areas and the very central area of Nunapitchuk, Kasigluk and Atmaulluak".

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: IT WILL SPILL
description: This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for kuveciquq, B stands for kuv'ciquq, and C stands for kuvciquq . For the Yup’ik item—It will spill--Jacobson examines a “‘hatted’ e (an e which is in a position whereby were it another vowel it would be rhythmically lengthened) which arises during word construction.” An e is retained and the following consonant is germinated in Norton Sound Unaliq and is deleted in the rest of Yup’ik unless it is between consonants. He notes, in Hooper Bay- Chevak, in Egegik and most peripheral GCY “if deletion of a ‘hatted’ e causes a voiced fricative to be followed by a stop or voiceless fricative the fricative in question stays voiced (as shown by the apostrophe). In core GCY and in Nunivak if a fricative ends up being followed by a stop or voiceless fricative for that reason that the fricative in question becomes voiceless.” The author also points out that areas using kuveciquq would also use germinated ll for nerelleq ‘the one that ate,’ and areas using kuv'ciquq would say ner’lleq, and areas using kuvciquq would say nerrleq.

name: Language Atlas of China: Mandarin in Eastern China
Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: JUMPING
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for mecegluni, B stands for qecegluni, and C stands for qeckargluni. For the Yup’ik item—Jumping--Jacobson discusses that qeckar-, the most widespread Yup’ik verb base for ‘to jump’, is from qeceg- with a postbase meaning ‘suddenly’. The postbase has become fused to the base in many areas so qeceg- alone is used in certain outlying areas. He also notes that cognates of the expanded base qeckar- are used both to the north and south of Yup’ik. Meceg- is limited to the area in contact with Inupiaq. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: KASS'AQ (MEANING)
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for white person (caucasian) and B stands for priest. For the Yup’ik item—Kass'aq (meaning)--Jacobson notes that kass'aq is used for ‘priest’ rather than ‘white person’ in the Nushagak, Lake Iliamna areas, and Alutiiq, and elsewhere in Yup’ik uses agayulirta for ‘priest’ and kassaakaq for ‘white person’. He also suggests that areas use kass’aq have longer history of Russian influence but its etymology is unclear. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: "SALMON BERRY," CLOUDBERRY
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for aqavsik, B stands for aqevyik, C stands for atsalugpiaq, D stands for atsarpiaq, E stands for atsaq, and F stands for naunraq, and G stands for epulek . For the Yup’ik item—"Salmon berry", cloudberry—Jacobson suggests that aqavsik/ aqevyik is the original Yup’ik name and has cognates in other Eskimo. He also notes that this word is limited to Norton Sound Unaliq and Hooper Bay-Chevak within Yup’ik. All the words reflect the important role of this kind of berry in Yup’ik life except for epulek ‘one with a handle or stem' which is the descriptive Egegik localism. Finally, he points out that atsaq means just ‘berry’ and naunraq means just ‘plant’ in the areas where these words don’t mean ‘salmonberry’. Atsarpiaq and atsalugpiaq mean ‘genuine, original berry’. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: WOMAN'S OR SEMILUNAR KNIFE, "ULU"
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for uluaq while B stands for ulukaq, and C stands for kegginalek. According to Jacobson, the two forms forWoman’s or semilunar knife are uluaq (with variant ulukaq) and kegginalek. The word uluaq is used almost everywhere in Yup’ik, while the word kegginalek is found only in Hooper Bay. Thus the word kegginalek is a local innovation with the literal meaning ‘one with a sharp edge (kegginaq, basically ‘face’)’. name: Language Atlas of China: Mandarin in Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region
Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: BECAUSE I LEFT
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distributions maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for ayagngama while B stands for ayiima, and C stands for asiima. For the Yup’ik item—Because I Left—Jacobson notes that the suffix is used with “consequential verb mood”: in one pattern the marker is +nga-, as in ayagngama ‘because I left’. Another pattern is from core GCY area: (ng)a-, such as ayiima from ayagama. Golovin, a village far from core GCY, also uses a variant of ayiima. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: BUMBLE BEE
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distributions maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for (e)vegtaq, B stands for megtaq, C stands for panayuli, D stands for uuqnikuq, and E stands for uuqnituq. For the Yup’ik item—Bumble bee—Jacobson notes that (e)vegtaq ‘thing of the grass’ (the general eskimo word) is used for ‘bee’. Megtaq is a variant of (e)vegtaq and may be the imitative sound of bee. Uuqnikuq and uuqnituq are “localisms” said by children to bees. Panayuli ‘one that is good at spearing’ is a "regionalism" according to Jacobson. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: CROWBERRY
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for paunraq, B stands for tan'gerpak, and C stands for kavlakuaraq. For the Yup’ik item—Crowberry--Jacobson notes that paunraq has been the original Yup’ik name for small black berry and now is used in most Eskimo, the north of Yup’ik, outlaying Nunivak, and Egegik. Tan'gerpak, literally means ‘big blackness,’ is the most widespread Yup’ik name. Kavlakuaraq means ‘small bearberry' (kavlak) in Hooper Bay- Chevak localism. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: ONE HUNDRED
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for kavluun, B stands for talliman ipiaq, C stands for yuinaat talliman, and D stands for negavaq. For the Yup’ik item—One hundred—Jacobson notes that 20 is the base on the Eskimo numerical system, so yuinaat talliman literally means ‘five twenties’, and talliman ipiaq is the same idea and one can see the discussion of ipiaq instead of yuinaq at FORTY. Surprisingly there are two words for 100 and may be from post-contact. The author speculates that kavluun may be a loan “used for primer caps which came in packs of 100”, and negavaq sounds like it is from negaq ‘snare, mesh of net’, and could be related to some net measurement. This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. For the Yup’ik item—Patch on garment—Jacobson addresses the distribution that follows the core GCY vs. peripheral GCY pattern. According to the author, neither word is a (recent) innovation which is unlike many other cases. One can find cognates of both callmak and ilaaq (means ‘addition’ in Alutiiq) to north and south of Yup’ik. name: Language Atlas of China: Mandarin in Shaanxi, Gansu, Qinghai and Ningxia Provinces
Cameroon: Mefele speaking villages-LL-MAP
title: Mefele-speaking villages in Cameroon
description:
The map shows the locations of four villages where Shugule, Mouhour, Mefele and Sirak are spoken. It was created using data from Karyn Crawford's work on Mefele (Crawford 2005). Mefele is spoken in the Far North Province of Cameroon, Mayo-Tsanaga Division, Mokolo Subdivision. The dialects, which generally consist of one village each and which are named after that village, are located near Mokolo (Crawford 2005)- the sixth-largest city in the province. Crawford gives the following population data for the villages:
Village 1987 Census 2002 Estimate
Shugule 3419 4906
Mouhour 506 726
Moufouélé 1899 2725
Sirak 1880 2698
Total 7604 10,912
source:
Map was created with data from [ 
		Crawford, Karyn 2005 Lexicostatistics and Intelligibility Testing Survey with Simplified SLOPE of the Mefele Language. 
		SIL Electronic Report](http://www.sil.org/silesr/2005/silesr2005-021.pdf), and from [the National Geospatial intelligence Agency's online coordinate database](http://geonames.nga.mil)
creator: Susanne Vejdemo, GISLI Stockholm

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: BOAT
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distributions maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for angsaq, B stands for angyaq, C stands for palayaq. For the Yup’ik item—boat—Jacobson notes that this area says angsaq instead of angyaq due to "Norton Sound Unaliq"; "after a consonant which closes a stressed syllable one always has s rather than y”. It is same in Kotlik, Mountain Village, and Marshall. Palayaq may be a blend with a Filipino loan palayu +Yup’ik yaq. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: BUCKET
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distributions maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. For the Yup’ik item—bucket—Jacobson notes that qaltaq ‘bucket’ is the pan-Eskimo word and tuqmik is used in southernmost Yup’ik. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: CLIFF, RIVER BANK
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for ekvik or neqlernaq, B stands for peńaq, C stands for epnaq, and D stands for igceńeq or igcineq. For the Yup’ik item—Cliff, river bank—Jacobson notes that ekvik is used for ‘river bank’ and peńaq/epnaq for ‘cliff’ in places where both words are used. Peńaq/epnaq is more common in coastal areas because there are seaside cliffs there. He also explains that igceńeq/ igcineq means ‘a drop off’ and is from igte- ‘to fall’. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: PIKE (FISH)
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for cuukvak, B stands for cukvak, C stands for qalru, D stands for luqruuyak, E stands for keggsuli, and F stands for ciulek. For the Yup’ik item—Pike (fish)—Jacobson notes that luqruuyak is a rare loan word from Athabaskan (PORCUPINE is another), and what's surprising is that the upper Kuskokwim (that divides the Yup’ik luqruuyak area and Athabaskan territory) uses qalru which is not a loan word. BothKeggsuli literally ‘good biter’ and ciulek ‘one with a front’ are “appropriate descriptive terms” for this fish. Cuukvak (predictable variant cukvak with “vowel compression”, see also KNEE) also occurs in luqruuyak area in the form of cuukvaguaq ‘alder tree’, literally ‘pretend, or one like, a cuukvak’. Its etymology could be from the bark of an alder that resemble pike skin on coloration. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: PORCUPINE
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for ilaanquciq, B stands for nuuniq, C stands for issaluuq, D stands for issaluq, and E stands for cukilek. For the Yup’ik item—Porcupine--Jacobson notes that nuuniq is a rare Yup’ik word from Athabaskan and is surprisingly found in the places that do not border Athabaskan territory, such as Kotlik, the Yukon delta, and the middle Yukon. He suggests that issaluuq/ issaluq may be a loan because its usual phonology, and the same form means ‘flock of birds take off in flight’ from Aleut. Like other groups, Yup’ik believes that porcupines shoot out their quills. Cukilek, literally means ‘one with quills’, is used for ‘stickleback’ in some areas as well. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: ROPE (OF TWISTED FIBER)
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for milu'uvkaaq, B stands for pilu'uvkaaq, C stands for ilavkuku, D stands for qip'arpak, and E stands for qecik. For the Yup’ik item—Rope (of twisted fiber)—Jacobson notes milu'uvkaaq/ pilu'uvkaaq is from Russian veryо́vka and may be the source of ilavkuku. The apical “r” in place of Yup’ik l in the Alutiiq cognate of ilavkuku indicates the Russian origin. However, these two forms milu'uvkaaq/ pilu'uvkaaq and ilavkukuare so different that it is hard to see that they are the same Russian source. Finally, the author explains the localism qip'arpak which literally means ‘big twisted thing’ and qecik ‘hide’. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: "DOG" OR CHUM SALMON
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for iqalluk, B stands for teggmaarrluk , C stands for kangitneq, D stands for aluyak, E stands for neqpik, and F stands for mac'utaq. For the Yup’ik item—"Dog" or chum salmon--Jacobson notes that iqalluk may be the proto-Eskimo word for ‘fish, especially salmon’. Teggmaarrluk is from tegge- ‘to be tough’, kangitneq may be from kangiq ‘source.’ Neqpik literally means ‘real/true fish’ and is used in several separated areas, which does not suggest dialectal link. Contrary to neqpik, mac'utaq does suggest the dialectal link that used in Nunivak and Egegik. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: EGG
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for manik, B stands for peksuq, and C stands for kayanguq. For the Yup’ik item—Egg-Jacobson notes that the distribution of peksuq and kayanguq represents the core vs. peripheral GCY theme. When kayanguq is used in some areas for ‘egg’, peksuq is used in the verb form peksute- ‘to find eggs’ (+te- is the postbase ‘to catch, get’). Furthermore, Jacobson also points out that manik is presented in the derived form manignaq ‘burbot, loshe’ with postbase +naq ‘animal, especially fish,’ and is found only in extreme north of Yup’ik and almost pan-Eskimo outside of Yup’ik. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: HEY YOU, WHAT ARE YOU DOING?
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for usuuq, casit?, and B stands for uyuuq, cayit?, C stands for uyuuq, casit?, D stands for usuuq, cayit?. For the Yup’ik item—Hey you, what are you doing? --Jacobson discusses the phonological distribution. Both words have y in Hooper Bay- Chevak due to lack of voiced s, in Egegik due to voiced s occurs only preceding e, in part of peripheral GCY (upriver Yukon, the upper Kuskokwim, and the Lake Iliamna area) due to s’s occurrence in preconsonantal only, and in core GCY and extension to the Yukon delta, the middle Yukon, Nelson Is, Canineq, and the Nushagak due to s’s “deep germination (as in usuuq) and when 'deeply' followed by i" according to Jacobson. He also notes that Norton Sound Unaliq uses cayit because “one gets (voiced) s when germinated intervocallically and usuuq because one gets (voiced) s when germinated”. y in Nunivak intervocallically one when ungerminated only and voiceless s when germinated. Therefore, usuuq is pronounced as ussuur. Finally he points out the evident s pattern that casit but uyuuq from Marshall, Holy Cross and Kalskag is due to “deeply” followed by i in core GCY, but unlike core GCY “deep” germination does not cause voiced s. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: I ATE IT
description: This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for nerellruaqa, B stands for nerelqaqa, and C stands for neither (ner'aqa used instead). For the Yup’ik item—I ate it—Jacobson discusses that the item assesses whether the past transitive (at least for the indicative) is with the postbase –llru- or –lqe-. Norton Sound Unaliq uses neither base, rather past (for intransitive and transitive) is expressed throughout context. –llru-, used for past transitive, is an innovation because it contains the postbase ~:(ng)u- ‘to be’ that usually takes intransitive endings. He suggests that the use of –lqe- instead of –llru- for transitive in Upper Kuskokwim may be the “evidence for E.W. Nelson version of the Aglurmiu hypothesis”. He also notes that in nerellruaqa for ‘I ate it’ areas one can use nerelqaqa with subtle difference, ‘it’s the thing I ate’.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: KNEE
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for ciisquq, and B stands for cisquq. For the Yup’ik item—Knee—Jacobson discusses the ‘compression” feature of the item, which is “the process by which two vowels (alike or unlike) in a closed syllable have the length of a single vowel (but the stress of two vowels). He notes that the divergent dialects of Yup’ik (except Norton Sound) and Alutiiq have compression, and this supports the Aglurmiut hypothesis. Scammon Bay and its neighboring Hooper Bay- Chevak have compression in common in other respects (see MY HOUSE & ITS WATER etc.). he also suggests that the compression in the upper Kuskowkim may be a convergent development and may support the E.W. Nelson version of the Aglurmiut hypothesis. The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: WHO OWNS IT?
description: This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for kia pikau?, B stands for kia pikagu?, C stands for kia pikaung?, D stands for kitum pikau?. For the Yup’ik item—Who owns it?—According to Jacobson, the item addresses the distribution of the traditional relative case of kina ‘who’, kia, and regularized form kitum (compare kitumek ‘from whom’, kitumun ‘to whom’ etc). Both the regularized form (used often by the young people) and the traditional form are found on Nelsion Is, the Canineq area, and Bristol Bay. Also, he notes that kiam, an alternative to kia, could be from kia-am "or a relative case marker m tacked onto the (already relative case) form kia." The special variants of pikau are used in Golovin and Nunivak, and the Golovin form is similar to Inupiaq forms.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: WII (pronunciation)
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for voiced fricative [w], B stands for voiceless fricative [w̥], and C stands for stop [kw]. For the Yup’ik item—Wii (pronunciation)—Jacobson notes that the phoneme occurs primarily in the beginning of the words such as wii or wiinga ‘I’, wangkuta ‘we’, watua ‘just now’, and wani ‘right here’. One of the few features the Hooper Bay- Chevak (and some adjoining Nelson Is.) and in Norton Sound share is the voiced fricative, while elsewhere in Yup’ik is voiceless fricative except for Nunivak. The phoneme is written uniformly as w whether voiced or voiceless except for Nunivak where it is a stop [kʷ], which would write as kw. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: WOLVERINE
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for qavcik while B stands for terikaniaq. Jacobson points out that the two cognates for the word ‘Wolverine’ are qavcik and terikaniaq. The distribution of the two forms still has the same north vs. south pattern. The cognate of qavcik, which means ‘wolverine’, is found in all Eskimo languages north of Yup’ik, while cognates of terikaniaq, which means ‘arctic fox’, is found in North Alaskan, Canadian and Greenlandic Inupiaq or Inuit. It is worthy to note that the Yup’ik for ‘marten’ is qavcicuaq, the literal meaning of which is ‘small wolverine’. In addition, qavcicuaq is found in areas where terikaniaq is used rather than in the areas where qavcik is used for ‘wolverine’. name: Sri Lanka: Indian Tamil Speaking Enclaves (Breton)
title: Sri Lanka: Indian Tamil Speaking Enclaves
description:
'Indian Tamil' refers to the dialect of Tamil spoken on mainland India. This dialect was brought to Sri Lanka by immigrants, and blended with a number of indigenous Sri Lankan languages. While it is considered a 'Tamil' dialect, it is distinctive when compared to the Tamil spoken in Tamil Nadu on mainland India. 
Notes on reading this map:
This map is designed to be overlaid onto other maps of Sri Lanka, in order to gain a more in depth view of the languages spoken on the island.

name: Linguistic Survey of India: Siamese-Chinese Languages
description:
The Linguistic Survey of India (LSI) was a survey of the languages of British India, conducted in the first several decades of the 20th century by the British Raj and directed by Irish linguist George A Grierson. This particular map shows the Siamese-Chinese languages in what was then India and Burma.

On LSI maps of language families, such as this one, it is not always clear or consistent whether names refer to languages or subgroups. In our digitized versions, we have included the maximal language coding possible (i.e. if a name could refer to either a language or a subgroup, we include codes for both).

Note for reading these maps: The original LSI maps do not indicate boundaries or areas for all languages/dialects. This is why some language/dialect names appear simply as labels, while others appear as areas. That is, these two categories of labels are not meaningfully different (i.e. they do not represent different subgroups or anything similar) unless the legend specifically indicates otherwise.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: LET'S LEAVE
description: This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for ayiilta, B stands for asiilta, and C stands for ayalta. For the Yup’ik item—Let's leave—Jacobson discusses the suffixation pattern of the ending 'let’s –': one pattern is (e)lta, as in ayiilta ‘let’s leave’, itrelta ‘let’s enter’, etc., and the other pattern is -lta, giving ayalta and itelta for the same items. the author notes that the first one is a northern pattern and the second southern pattern. The first pattern is used by older speakers and the second younger speakers reported by the four villages in the Bethel area. The author suggests that the area is shifting from the northern to the southern pattern.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: OAR
description: This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for yavun, B stands for cavun, C stands for savun, and D stands for utqerrun. For the Yup’ik item—Oar—Jacobson argues that the forms yavun, cavun, and savun “do not correspond to a more general pattern of initial y, c, and s (compare PERSON)”. The verb bases to these words are yave-, cave-, save-, and utqerr- ‘to row’.

name: Language Atlas of China: Minority Languages on Taiwan Island
description: This map illustrates the locations of minority languages on the island of Taiwan. All of those displayed here are the Austronesian languages spoken by indigenous Taiwanese; many such indigenous Taiwanese languages have already disappeared altogether, and the remaining ones are endangered. Wurm and Liu also refer to the speakers of these languages as a single nationality, "Gaoshan" (lit. "high mountain"), but the various indigenous Taiwanese are not monoethnic.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: Dialects of Central Alaskan Yup'ik
title: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: Central Alaskan Yup'ik Dialects
description:
This map shows Jacobson's overall conclusions as to the locations of the various Central Alaskan Yup'ik dialects and subdialects, as well as some of the other regions to which he refers throughout the Study. Please note that rivers and villages are part of this map, but have been turned off in the default view to avoid clutter; if you would like to view them, click the appropriate boxes in the legend.

Several important features of this map require some explanation: - The apportionment of land to different dialects is not especially meaningful; the purpose of the map is to show which villages are in which areas. For instance, the Norton Sound Kotlik subdialect consists only of the village of Kotlik; the two-dimensional area it encompasses is presumably for graphical convenience. - The "transitional zones" indicate regions in which speakers cannot be definitively classified into either of the adjacent dialects. - The "special areas" are not dialects, but they are linguistically significant groupings, in which "a number of lexical (and to a lesser extent, phonological) features cut across dialect and subdialect boundaries." - On the original map, Jacobson divides the Kuskokwim and Yukon rivers into lower, middle, and upper regions, with approximate boundaries. These do not represent linguistically differentiated areas, but are useful for making geographic reference to certain places throughout the Atlas. These boundaries have been left off this map for the sake of space, but you may view them by clicking the original image link.

Finally, Jacobson also points out that his dialect areas correspond very little to maps of Yup'ik "tribes" produced by other scholars (and generally calls into question the validity of the concept of "tribes" with respect to the Yup'ik).

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: STICKLEBACK, "NEEDLEFISH"
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for quarruuk, B stands for cukilek, and C stands for ilaqcungaq. For the Yup’ik item—Stickleback, "needlefish"—Jacobson notes that quarruuk is the true name for this fish except in Norton Sound. Cukilek (literally ‘one with quills’) is a nickname and used for PORCUPINE in some areas. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: STONE, ROCK
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for teggalquq, B stands for tegalquq, C stands for ciimaq, D stands for siimaq, and E stands for yaamaq. For the Yup’ik item—Stone, rock—Jacobson notes that the contrast case of SQUIRREL and FISH SCALE--ciimaq--the northern Yup’ik word for ‘stone’, does not appear to the north of Eskimo languages, nor does it occurs as siimaq in Nunivak in the Nushagak River and Egegik, which supports the Aglurmiut hypothesis. The author suggests that yaamaq in Egegik and Alutiiq is possibly a cognate. Teggalquq/ tegalquq is from tegg- ‘to be hard’, and the voiced g in the second variant is regular compared to kegluneq ‘wolf’ and keglerluku ‘taking quite a bite out of it’, from kegge- ‘to bite’. SLIPPING is a similar case found in Hooper Bay-Chevak and upper Kuskokwim. The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: RIB
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for pengraliq, and B stands for tulimaq, C stands for tulimaraq, and D stands for inarun. For the Yup’ik item—Rib—Jacobson notes that the general Eskimo word for ‘rib’ in Yup’ik-- tulimaq/ tulimaraq-- is the core GCY word. The peripheral GCY word inarun literally means ‘device for lying down’ and “is similar to the various instrumentals used as substitutes for anatomical terms in core GCY” according to the author. Pengraliq—the Norton Sound Unaliq word-- occurs down in Alutiiq and may from pere- ‘to bend’ and the stative postbase –nga-. The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: SCRATCHING (AN ITCH)
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. The author also suggests that the situation "prevails in North Alaskan Inupiaq where the cognates of kumeg- means ‘to scratch’ and the cognate of paume- means ‘to itch’". name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: STICKING UP FOR HIM
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for igurluku and B stands for (e)yurluku. For the Yup’ik item—Sticking up for him—Jacobson discusses whether the intervocalic g in the verb base igur- ‘to stick up for, to defend verbally’ has been deleted to form *iur- and therefore eyur-. He argues that the four divergent dialects use the older form and kept g, but scattered GCY villages also use this form and sometimes as the only form. One can compare this item to the intervocalic v in SONG. The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: STOVE
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for keńervik, B stands for kenirvik, C stands for pelit'aaq, and D stands for kaminiaq. For the Yup’ik item—Stove—Jacobson notes that pelit'aaq and kaminiaq are the two most common Yup’ik words coming from Russian (like the device itself). It is common to use two Russian loans for the same thing (see HORSE).The familiar north vs. south distribution pattern hold for the two words, illustrating that the underlying pattern was kept after Russians came. Pelit'aaq and kaminiaq are from traditional dual purpose stove for heating and cooking. The term kenircuun refers to a stove used for cooking only and is also used for ‘campstove’. The native words keńervik and kenirvik literally mean ‘place for fire’ and ‘place to cook’ respectively. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: SUN
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for macaq, B stands for puqlaneq, and C stands for akerta. For the Yup’ik item—Sun—Jacobson notes that the usual Yup’ik word for ‘sun’, akerta, is unknown for its etymology and has no cognates elsewhere. Macaq, in Yup’ik only in Norton Sound Unaliq, has cognates to the north and south of Yup’ik and may also be the original Eskimo word for ‘sun’. Puqlaneq, from puqla ‘heat’, is a controversial case because it would seem to be a localism but it occurs in both Nunivak and Egegik which supports the Aglurmiut hypothesis. Its use in the far upper Kuskokwim may also support the E.W. Nelson version of the hypothesis. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: THINKING
description: This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for umsugarteqluni, B stands for umsuarteqluni, C stands for umyuarteqluni, D stands for umyugarturluni, and E stands for umyugiurluni. For the Yup’ik item—Thinking—Jacobson addresses some important factors the items illustrate. Firstly, he notes the use of (voiced) s rather than y in Norton Sound, and the retention of intervocalic g in Norton Sound Unaliq, Hooper Bay- Chevak, and Egegik. Secondly, he points out that the differing postbase are used to expand the basic word umyu(g)aq/ umsu(g)aq. Finally, he suggests that Hooper Bay-Chevak and Egegik using the same form supports the Aglurmiut hypothesis.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: UNDERSTANDING HIM
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: WALRUS
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for asveq, B stands for kaugpak, and C stands for qecigpak. For the Yup’ik item—Walrus—Jacobson notes that kaugpak is an alternative to the pan-Eskimo term asveq and also a central coast innovation based on an obsolete word *kauk--a cognate to the Inupiaq word for ‘edible walrus skin’. Kaugpak was spread by Nunivak walrus hunters coming up to the Kuskokwim selling walrus. Qecigpak in Egegik and Lake Iliamna has the same derivation to kaugpak because qecik means ‘skin,hide’. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: WEASEL
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for aklanqurrun, B stands for narullgiq, C stands for narulkiaq, D stands for amitatuk, and E stands for teriaq. For the Yup’ik item—Weasel—Jacobson notes narullgiq and its unpredictable variant narulkiaq are the most common Yup’ik word for ‘weasel’ and have no cognates outside Yup’ik. Aklanqurrun is the only Yup’ik animal name incorporating the postbase –un ‘device for’ or ‘supply of’, and it has no cognates either. Outside of Yup’ik, amitatuk is found in Alutiiq, Naukanki and Sirenikski, and within Yup’ik it is used in Egegik, Hooper Bay- Chevak and the Yukon delta. Teriaq has Inupiaq cognates and is reported from very few sporadic Yup’ik places and never as the only word for ‘weasel’. The author suggests that it “may be a particular type or the winter color phase of the weasel (ermine).” The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: WEATHER, WORLD, AWARENESS
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for ella, B stands for cella, and C stands for cilla. For the Yup’ik item—Weather, world, awareness—Jacobson suggests that cilla could be the original form as still in Hooper Bay- Chevak and Egegik (and as supported by the i in the Naukanski form and by the “strong” i in the Inupiaq form). From i to e reduction has happened in Siberian Yup’ik, most Yup’ik, and Alutiiq. Words beginning originally with ci followed by an apical are in a similar situation, such as sitaman/ cetaman ‘four’ and cińa/ceńa ‘shore’. The deletion of initial c preceding ell represents the core GCY phenomenon that has spread to Nunivak and Alutiiq. Other similar cases to cilla becoming cella which becomes ella in the area are: cilli-/celli-/elli- ‘to whet’, and cilleg-/ celleg-/ elleg- ‘to be thick around, to be stout’. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: WHEN HE SAW ME
description: This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for 1st contemporative mood not used, B stands for tangellrania, and C stands for tangellranga. For the Yup’ik item—When he saw me—Jacobson notes that 1st contemporative mood ‘when one –ed’ is an Yup'ik innovation and only found in Yup’ik. Derived from the localis due to its localis ending ni on intransitive forms such as qavallemni ‘when I slept’ (compare quavarpailegma ‘before I slept’), ni is also found between the subject and object markers of transitive forms with a 4th person subject such as tangllerminia ‘when he (subject) saw me’. As the map indicates, ni in transitive forms with a 3rd or 2nd person singular subject is used primarily in the central coastal region. Areas using tangellrania instead of tangellranga also says tangllerpeniu instead of tangllerpegu as elsewhere for ‘when you saw him’. Finally, the author points out that the same remnant of localis is used with the 2nd contemporative mood (‘while one –s’). Therefore, tangva(gng)inanraniq and tangva(gng)inanerpeniu are used instead of tangva(gng)inanranga and tangva(gng)inanerpegu for ‘while he was watching me’ and ‘while you were watching him’.

description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. Thus, in this map, A stands for tupuk, B stands for qaurtuq, C stands for naptaq, D stands for akakiik, E stands for uraruq, F stands for cavirrutnaq, and G stands for qanerkicaq. For the Yup’ik item—Whitefish—Jacobson notes that tupuk is the Yup’ik word only used in Norton Sound Unaliq which is also cognate to a word in other Eskimo. Of other Yup’ik words, akakiik may be from akag- ‘to roll’, naptaq literally means ‘one that is caught, as in a net’, and qanerkicaq is from ‘mouth’. The rest words are unknown for their etymologies. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: (HE) ASKS HER TO ENTER
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for itresqaa while B stands for itesqaa. For the Yup’ik item—(He) asks her to enter—Jacobson notes the suffixation pattern. The first pattern, :(e)sqe- is subject to intervocalic velar dropping while the second pattern –sqe- is consonant dropping. The first pattern is used by older speakers and is probably the original. The second is used by younger speakers and is probably an innovation. The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: REGULARLY HE USES IT
description: This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for aturlaraa, B stands for atularaa, and C stands for neither (atutua used instead). For the Yup’ik item—Regularly he uses it —Jacobson discusses the postbase meaning ‘to regularly-‘ that whether it retains or deletes final consonants of verb bases. The result shows north vs. south pattern. He also notes that –tu- is used instead of the postbase in Nunivak and Hooper Bay- Chevak, and is also used in the places where +lar-/-lar- is possible.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: RUFF FOR PARKA HOOD
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for negiliq, B stands for legiliq, C stands for asguruaq, D stands for ayguruaq, E stands for pugyaraq, and F stands for ulganaq. For the Yup’ik item—Ruff for parka hood—Jacobson notes the north vs. south pattern and suggests a core GCY naming taboo because negiliq (negiqliq sic) is a personal name in that region, and asguruaq is a descriptive term meaning ‘similar to, or pretend, going against the (wind) current.’ Ulganaq, the Nunivak word, is related to uulegte- ‘to shake, tremble’. The localism pugyaraq, from puge- ‘to surface’, refers to the way one’s head surfaces through a parka ruff. The author also notes the Chevak form legiliq of negiliq, "is the opposite situation from Nunivak having luussiq for KNIFE where others have nuussiq". name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: SHORTENING
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for saalaq, B stands for caalaq, and C stands for mantiikaq. For the Yup’ik item—Shortening—Jacobson notes that the words for ‘shortening’ are post-contact, and saaluq/ caaluq is from Russian sа́lo. One can consult TEA & SUGAR for the distribution of the c and s forms, but the author notes that “there is a difference in the Yukon between the treatment of ‘shortening’ and of ‘sugar’ which both come from Russian s words”. Mantiikaq is from Spanish manteca, so the author speculates that Filipino cannery workers may have brought this word to the greater Bristol Bay area. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: SLEEVE
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for aliq, and B stands for amraq. For the Yup’ik item—Sleeve—Jacobson notes that aliq is the Yup’ik form of the pan-Eskimo word for ‘sleeve’ and has been replaced by amraq (Aleut origin) in the areas of heavy Russian influence. The author suggests that Aleut loan words in Yup’ik pre-dates Russian times and could be due to “hunting/fishing based word taboo” since these loan words are often animal names such as cagiq/sagiq ‘flounder’, qakiiyaq ‘silver salmon’, and etc. The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for qavarniluni, and B stands for qavaraluni. For the Yup’ik item—(Being) sleepy— Jacobson notes that qavara-, the northern Yup’ik verb base for ‘to be sleepy’, is also used in the south for ‘to doze off intermittently’. He suggests that this may explain the reports of both forms being used in Nelson Is, Canieq and the lower Kuskokwim. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: WILD RUHBARB
description: This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for nauciq, B stands for nakaaq, C stands for angukaq, D stands for naunraq. For the Yup’ik item—Wild rhubarb—Jacobson notes that the distribution of the names follows the coast vs. inland pattern, and the plant is not found in all Yup’ik areas. Cognates of angukaq and nakaaq are found in other Eskimo languages as names for other plants. Nauciq and naunraq come from nau- ‘to grow’, and naunraq means ‘plant’ to most Yup’iks and sometimes SALMONBERRY.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 1 "großer Heuschober"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 1 "Large Haystack"
description: The first map in the Sorbischer Sprachatlas details not only the pronunciation, but also the geographical areas where a particular Sorbian word is used to describe a popular method of creating winter-time haystacks. South of the isogloss of this map, the lexeme is known, but not commonly used.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: MOTHER
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for aakaq, B stands for aana, and C stands for caqun. For the Yup’ik item—Mother—Jacobson notes that Norton Sound Unaliq uses a word same as Inupiaq while the Asiatic Eskimo languages shares a word with non-Unaliq Yup’ik and Alutiiq. Also, there are other similar cases where “Unaliq (or northern Yup’ik in general) use the same word with Inupiaq bypassing Asiatic Eskimo (see example FISH SCALE)”. From this, the author argues that there is no such “a simple linear gradient runs from Kuskokwim Central Yup’ik though Yukon, Unaliq, Asiatic Eskimo and then on to Inupiaq”. Finally, he points out that caqun (literally ‘wrapping’) is more widespread than reported place, and also “Barnum’s 1901 grammar mentions it and was primarily on Nelson Is and the areas to the north of it.” The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: WOOD
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distributions maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for equk while B stands for muraq and C stands for muragaq. For the Yup’ik item—Wood—Jacobson notes that murak/muragaq has no cognates outside Yup’ik. Equk is an older form than murak for ‘wood,’ and is also found in murak/muragaq areas in equgtar- ‘to get firewood,’ in eqiur- ‘to chop wood,’ and in eqir- ‘to stoke’. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: WRITING
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for alngarluni while B stands for igarluni. The two verb bases for Writing are: igaq which originally means ‘marking’, and alngaq which originally means ‘decoration, especially on a parka’. Jacobson points out that neither of these two post-contact bases is borrowed from Russian. The distribution of the usage of the bases for ‘writing’ is similar to that for HORSE and STOVE, which is a typical north vs. south pattern. In contrast, however, both HORSE and STOVE are Russian loan words. The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: YOU, ANSWER ME!
description: This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for kiugia while B stands for kiunga. Jacobson notes that there are two forms of ‘you to me’ optative ending with verb bases which end in two vowels. For instance, the verb base for kiu- (‘to answer’) ends with two vowels. The two forms for the optative kiu- are: kiugia and kiunga. Jacobson also points out that both the two forms are used in most areas. However, only the usage of Kiunga is found in the following areas: most of the greater Bristol Bay area, the upper Kuskokwim and upriver Yukon, and most parts of the divergent dialects. Thus, according to Jacobson, kiunga is the original form from which kiugia derives. There is no conclusive data found for the Non-Yup'ik Languages in this region.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: POOR THING!
description: This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for akleng, and B stands for nakleng. For the Yup’ik item—Poor thing!—Jacobson notes that only nakleng is used in outlying areas and thus could be the original, which goes with “the emotional root nakleg-'', as in naklegnarquq ‘it evokes compassion’. In addition to nakleng, akleng is also used around the mouth of the Kuskokwim area with the meaning ‘so sorry’ rather than ‘poor thing.’ The author points out that two forms started as phonological variants has obtained a semantic difference.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: PTARMIGAN
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for aqesgiq, and B stands for aqeygiq, C stands for qangqiiq. For the Yup’ik item—Ptarmigan--Jacobson discusses the distribution of north vs. south and/or core GCY vs. peripheral GCY. He notes that qangqiiq has no cognates outside of Yup’ik, and “the use of y rather than s in preconsonantal position in Hooper Bay-Chevak and Egegik (aqeygiq rather than aqesgiq) supports the Aglurmiut hypothesis." name: Senufo Languages (Public Content)
title: Senufo Language Area
description: The Senufo or Senufic languages (Senoufo in Francophone usage) comprise ca. 15 languages spoken by the Senufo in the north of Ivory Coast, the south of Mali and the southwest of Burkina Faso. An isolated language, Nafaanra, is also spoken in the west of Ghana. The Senufo languages are generally considered a branch of the Gur sub-family of Niger–Congo languages. Garber (1987) estimates the total number of Senufos at some 1.5 million; the Ethnologue, based on various population estimates, counts 2.7 million. The Senufo languages are bounded to the west by Mande languages, to the south by Kwa languages, and to the north and east by Central Gur languages.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: RAIN
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for ivsuk, B stands for ivyuk, C stands for cellalluk, and D stands for ellalluk. For the Yup’ik item—Rain—Jacobson discusses the distribution of ivyuk/ivsuk and cellalluk/ ellalluk following the coast vs. inland pattern far to south to Nelson Is. Regarding the question of y vs. s, surprisingly Nelson Is uses ivsuk instead of ivyuk which is very unusual for this area. So the author speculates that ivsuk is “a back formation from the verb ivsir- ‘to rain’ where the i would govern the choice of y or s”. He also points out that cognates of ivyuk/ivsuk is unusual in other Eskimo languages too. One can see WEATHER to address the question of initial c in cellalluk/ellalluk. The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.

description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. For the Yup’ik item—School—Jacobson notes the Yup’ik based words for ‘school’: naaqivik literally means ‘place to read’ and elitnaurvik/ elicarvik/ elissarvik ‘place to endeavor to learn’. (E)skuulaq and (e)skuuluq are from Russian and reinforced by English”. Finally he notes that the distribution pattern is a typical one with one word in Bristol Nay another in Kuskokwim, a third in the Yukon, and one more in the north. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: SKIN BOOT, "MUKLUK"
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for kamguk, B stands for kamesak, C stands for piluguk, and D stands for ac'iqaq. For the Yup’ik item—Skin boot, "mukluk"--Jacobson notes that the words here are the general form because one can find special words for specific type of skin boots in all areas. According to him, kamguk and kamesak are from “the unattested (in Yup’ik) *kamek, cognate to the word for ‘skin boot’ in all Eskimo languages north of Yup’ik”. A cognate of piluguk is found only in Siberian Yup’ik where it means ‘clothing’. Ac'iqaq, the Nunivak form, is from at’e- ‘to put on clothes’. Piluguk is the taller boot than kamesak in areas where both kamesak and piluguk are used. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: SLIPPING
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Thus, in this map, A stands for qurrasqilluni, B stands for ug͡asqilluni, C stands for quasqilluni, quasqiarrluni, and D stands for qurasqilluni. For the Yup’ik item—Slipping—Jacobson discusses the four variants of one basic form which is unpredictable regarding to the dialects in which they occur. He notes that the form and its distribution of ug͡asqilluni are interesting because very few words start with ug͡ “JACKRABBIT” is one). Also, this form is one of a small number of forms used only in the middle and upper Kuskokwim, upriver Yukon and sometimes the Lake Iliamna area (PIKE FISH is another). Finally the author points out that Egegik form is also found in Nunivak and Newtok which supports the Aglurmiut hypothesis. description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. Thus, in this map, A stands for neqleq, neqlernaq, B stands for leqleq, C stands for tuutangayak, D stands for lagilugpiaq, and E stands for lagilugpak. For the Yup’ik item—Canada goose—Jacobson notes that neqleq/ neqlernaq/ leqleq may be a general Eskimo word for various geese. Derived from tuutaq, tuutangayak is found only in Yup’pik. Lagilugpiaq is a loan from Aleaut, and lagiq has meaning of ‘goose’ in general. He also notes that -lugpiaq ‘genuine, original, old-style’ as a non-productive postbase found in other words such as Kass’alugpiaq ‘Russian.’ The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: CIGARETTE
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for kuingiq, B stands for kuiniq, C stands for meluguaq, D stands for melugkaq, E stands for puyurtuq, and F stands for imgayagaq. For the Yup’ik item—Cigarette—Jacobson notes that kuingiq/ kuiniq is a rare Yup’ik loan from Chukchi, which is a native Siberian language (AXE is another). It means ‘pipe’ only in all Eskimo languages north of Yup’ik, Norton Sound, and Yukon Yup’ik while it means ‘cigarette’ and ‘pipe’ in Canineq and lower and middle Kuskokwim. Meluguaq and melugkaq are derived from the verb base melug- ‘to suck’, puyurtuqp ‘to consume smoke’, and imgayagaq literally means ‘little rolled thing’. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for tutgaraq malruk, B stands for tutgar, C stands for tutgara'urluq , and D stands for elturaq . For the Yup’ik item—Grandchild-- Jacobson notes that tutgar and tutgaraq are predictable variants. Used mostly in peripheral GCY, tutgara'urluq has the postbase for ‘dear good old –' as in the case of maurluq ‘grandmother’ and apa’urluq ‘grandfather’. He also suggests that the use of elturaq may not be the evidence of the Aglurmiut hypothesis. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: HAND
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for aigga, B stands for aiggaq, C stands for aaggaq, and D stands for unan. For the Yup’ik item—Hand—Jacobson notes that unan, comes from an obsolete base una- ‘to work without tools’, is a core GCY innovation that has spread beyond the usual domain where aiggaq is used into disconnected parts. Aiggaq occurs in the common proper name aiggailnguq (literally ‘one without a hand’) in unan area. He also points out that the variant aaggaq is predictable for Nunivak. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: (HE) ISN'T AROUND
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for piituq while B stands for cataituq. For the Yup’ik item—(He) isn't around—Jacobson discusses the idiomatic meaning of these two verbs. Piituq literally means ‘he doesn't have a/the thing’, and the use of piituq for ‘he is not around, is absent’, dates back to proto-Eskimo. Cataituq literally means ‘there isn't anything’, and the use is only in Yup’ik.
