name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: I ALSO TALKED ABOUT THEM
description: This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for qánrutékagká-llu, B stands for qánrutkagká-llu, and C stands for qánrutkágka-llu. For the Yup’ik item—I also talked about them—Jacobson discusses the deletion of the e in an open syllable where if it is not a full vowel, “it would be rhythmically lengthened.” He notes that e is not deleted in Norton Sound Unaliq, “rather the following consonant (k in this case) is germinated thus closing the syllable”. According to the author, e is deleted in peripheral GCY; “the preceding vowel gets the stress that e would have had, and rhythmic stress assignment proceeds from there”. Also, e is deleted in core GCY, “and the word is re-evaluated for rhythmic stress just as if the e had never been there” which is the most extreme pattern according to Jacobson.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: LAUGHING
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for englarluni, B stands for ngel'arluni, C stands for nel'arluni, D stands for el'arluni, and E stands for nenglarluni. For the Yup’ik item—Laughing—Jacobson suggests that englarluni is the original form for ‘laughing’ according to comparative evidence and becomes ngel'arluni (underlying form [e]nglarluni) elsewhere in Yup’ik. He also notes that nel'arluni and el'arluni are derived from ngel'arluni because they do not use ng as words initial. According to the author, the initial n on nenglarluni may be “a parallel independent innovation” regarding to Siberian Yup’ik. Also, the initial n in the Egegik area and the upper Kuskokwim may support the E.W. Nelson version of the Aglurmiut hypothesis. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: LOUSE
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for kumak, B stands for neresta while C stands for ungilak. According to the author, "the most widespread Yup’ik word for 'louse' is neresta, which literally means 'eater'. The word ungilak, a direct nominalization of ungilag – 'to itch', is limited to the very core of core GCY. The word kumak is found everywhere north of Yup’ik, but within Yup’ik it is used only in Norton Sound Unaliq near Inupiaq, and also down in Egegik, which is surprising since it is not used in Alutiiq." Looking at other Eskimo languages, it appears that qup’luq/quvluq is the pan-Eskimo word for 'maggot'. Paraluq has no cognates outside of Yup’ik, and it is not so common to encounter a substitute Yup’ik word used in all the areas where paraluq is used. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: MITTEN
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for aritvak or arilluk, B stands for arin, C stands for kauman, D stands for aliiman, and E stands for aliuman. For the Yup’ik item—Mitten—Jacobson notes that the word arin (augmented forms arilluk, aritvak) for ‘mitten’ used in the divergent dialects of Yup’ik may mean ‘(big) device for ari-' and the verb base is unclear. He points out that ari- means ‘to get mashed’ in Yup’ik and ‘to become wet’ outside of Yup’ik, and neither fits the meaning ‘mitten’. Aliuman may literally mean ‘device to be, in an extended sense, a sleeve (aliq)’, which fits the meaning ‘mitten’ and aliiman can be a variant. Kauman literally ‘device to plunge one’s hand into’, is restricted to the Nelson Is. and Canineq. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: MY HOUSE & ITS WATER
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for enka & emra, B stands for enka & mer'a, C stands for nek'a & mer'a. For the Yup’ik item—My house & its water—Jacobson discusses whether the items does or does not have “weak” initial e on certain words. In Nunivak ena ‘house’ and emeq ‘water’ do not have weak initial e. Therefore, one says enka ‘my house’, enliut ‘they are making a house’, emra ‘its water’ or homophonously ‘drink’, emliraa ‘he diluted it’, etc. According to the author, in Hooper Bay- Chevak, Scammon Bay, and Egegik the initial e in ena is not weak except [e]meq. Therefore, one pronounces enka, enliut, mer’a, and mel’iraa for the same items. The initial e is weak in both [e]na and [e]meq in the rest of Yup’ik, so one says nek’a, neliut, mer’a, and mel’iraa for the same items. Finally, he points out that the initial e of ‘house’ and ‘water’ is audible only in words such enii ‘his house’ and emiumauq ‘it has been diluted’ (from [e]meliumauq). name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: (RIVER) OTTER
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for pirturciraq, B stands for cenkaq, C stands for cinkaq, D stands for cuignilnguq, and E stands for aaquyaq. For the Yup’ik item—(River) otter—Jacobson discusses the items that shows the common north vs. south pattern with four zones. Pirtuciraq (sic.) in the northernmost part of Yup’ik "is as in Eskimo to the north". The author argues that the division between cenkaq/cinkaq (the variation is predictable) and cuignilnguq is "not quite a horizontal line because upriver Yukon goes along with the Kuskokwim.” One can see the opposite situation in WHITEFISH. He points out that in the south aaquyaq in Egegik is as in Alutiiq. Also, pirtuciraq (sic.) occurs in Egegik but not found in Alutiiq, and one can see a similar situation in LOUSE. Finally, he notes that in Norton Sound which lacks stress retraction, the word is pronounced pírtucîraq but pírtúrciraq in Egegik. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: SMELT
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for elquarniq, B stands for cemerliq, C stands for cimerliq, D stands for qusuuq, E stands for quyuuq, F stands for iqalluaq, and G stands for uqtaqngaq. For the Yup’ik item—Smelt—Jacobson discusses the four Yup’ik words for ‘smelt’: "elquarniq in Norton Sound (and in Inupiaq to the north), qusuuq/ quyuuq in the Yukon, Kuskokwim, and Hooper Bay- Chevak, cemerliq/ cimerliq in some central coastal area and Lake Illiamna area, and iqalluaq in the greater Bristol Bay area." According to the author, elquarniq is related to elquaq which is a more widespread Yup’ik word for ‘herring eggs on seaweed’. Iqalluaq (means ‘arctic cod’ in the Yukon, Hooper Bay-Chevak and Nunivak) is from iqalluk, meaning ‘dog salmon’ in the Kuskokwim but is the general Eskimo word for ‘fish’ outside Yup’ik. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: SONG
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. For the Yup’ik item—Song—Jacobson discusses the item assessing whether that “the intervocalic v" in ivarun ‘song’ has been deleted to form yuarun. He speculates that a similar pattern applies to ivar- vs yuar ‘to look for’ and ivalug/yualug ‘sinew’. He notes that the deletion of v is a GCY and Norton Sound innovation. One can compare a similar distribution in deletion of intervocalic g in igurluku/ (e)yurluku STICKING UP FOR HIM. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: SOURDOCK, WILD SPINACH
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for quagciq, B stands for quunarliq, C stands for aatunaq, and D stands for civassaq. For the Yup’ik item—Sourdock, wild spinach—Jacobson notes that cognates of the most common Yup’ik term—quagciq--are found in Siberian Yup’ik and Naukanski Yup’ik but for a different plant. Both aatunaq in Hooper Bay- Chevak and Koniaq Alutiiq and civassaq in Nunivak and Egegik support the Aglurmiut hypothesis. The author also comments the occurrence of quunarliq in Kotlik and upper Kuskokwim surprising. Also, it appears in Levelock and Chugach Alutiiq which makes the author speculates that this may be "the case of convergence as quunarliq literally means ‘sour thing’". name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: SQUIRREL & MARMOT
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for "squirrel" = cikik, "marmot" = cikigpak, B stands for "squirrel" = qanganaq, "marmot" = cikigpak, C stands for "squirrel" = qanganaq, "marmot" = uiq, D stands for "squirrel" = cikik, no word for "marmot", and E stands for "squirrel" = qanganaq, no word for "marmot". For the Yup’ik item—Squirrel & marmot—Jacobson notes that cikik is only used by Norton Sound for ‘squirrel’ and qanganaq by the rest of Yup’ik (as in Alutiiq to the south). Also, a big part of Yup'ik uses cikigpak (literally ‘big cikik’) for ‘marmot’. Uiq (the second word for marmot) appears scarcely in the lower Kuskokwim and Bristol Bay and could be the cognate to qusXiq or quiXiq ‘marmot’ in Alutiiq. The author argues that marmots are uncommon in many places, so they have no word for this. Finally, he points out that qavcik WOLVERINE and qavcicuaq (literally ‘small quavcik’) is a similar situation to cikik and cikigpak. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: CROSSING IT
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for ek'rarluku, B stands for kerarluku, C stands for ker'arluku, D stands for qerarluku, E stands for qer'arluku, and F stands for qerrarluku. For the Yup’ik item—Crossing it--Jacobson notes that arvir- is used in and around Nelson Is, upper Kuskokwim, and upriver Yukon. Nirar- is used in Nushagak and Lake Iliamna area, and qerar- and its variants elsewhere. The options of k (Yukon) or q (elsewhere) in qerar-/kerar- follows the same pattern of qiuryaq/kiuryaq ‘aurora’. He also notes that the forms of qerar-/kerar- “with germinated or voiceless r are local variants,” and “ek'rar in Nunivak and Egegik is closer to the forms used in Inupiaq and Alutiiq.” The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: (HE MAY BE TRYING TO) DO SOMETHING AGAIN
description: This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for pínqigténgnaqsúgnarquq, while B stands for pinqígtengnáqsugnárquq. For the Yup’ik item—(He may be trying to) do something again--Jacobson notes the issue here is “whether the ‘empty’ base pi- ‘do, say’ ‘repels’ stress.” pinqíg- shows repelled stress, which is normal in the lower Kuskowim, the middle and upriver Yukon, and in western Bristol Bay, as well as in Hooper Bay-Chevak and Egegik. The form pínqig- shows non-repelled stress, which is used in Norton Sound (Unalakleet, Kotlik).

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 7 "*radlica"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 7 "Ard"
description: Map 7 presents the distribution of Sorbian pronunciations for 'ard' (Ger. Hakenpflugschar). All dialectal pronunciations stem from the same historical root, though metathesis and cluster reduction have created several different pronunciations across dialects.

name: Yup'ik Dialect Atlas and Study: (BEING) SICK
description:
This map comes from a series of individual maps of Yup'ik dialect differences. The distribution maps have been created from survey results completed by bilingual teachers in 61 out of 68 Yup’ik villages. While the respective points may be the same in size, this does not reflect the population density: some villages can have less than fifty speakers while others have populations up to a thousand. Please note: The letters correspond to the map's original image. Thus, in this map, A stands for nanglluni (base: nangte-), B stands for nangteqluni (base: nangteqe-), C stands for naulluuluni (base: naulluu-), and D stands for qenaluni (base: qena-). For the Yup’ik item—(Being)sick—Jacobson notes the item showing twice the north vs. south pattern. The northern part of Yup’ik uses nangte(qe)- “like adjoining Inupiaq”. Naulluu- is used in the middle part and qena- is used in the southern part also like “adjoining Alutiiq.” Nangte(qe)- (from nange- ‘to be depleted’) means ‘to suffer’ in areas using naulluu- or qena- for ‘to be sick.’ The author suggests that naulluu- may mean ‘to be (a) naulluuk’ where naulluuk would mean ‘(one with) bad vegetative grown.’ The table below shows Non-Yup'ik Languages that also share items of Yup'ik, the letters corresponding to the note above. The ones with an asterisk mean that there is no data found for the language.
Non-Yup’ik Languages Notation
North Alaskan Inupiaq A
Seward Peninsula Inupiaq A
Sirenikski *
(Central) Siberian Yupik X
Naukanski Yupik X
Konlag Alutiiq X
Chugach Alutiiq X

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 23 "Ähren (Suffix)"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 23 "Ears (of grain) (suffix)"
description: Map 23 documents the Sorbian dialect areas where suffixation occurs on the word root for 'ear (of grain)'. See Map 22 for details regarding the dialect forms of the word root.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 14 "Gewende"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 14 "Boundaries (between fields)"
description: This map details the various pronunciations of two lexemes all referring to Ger. Gewende 'boundary between fields'. The two different roots are indicative of major lexical differences across dialects, while general phonetic differences exist in the pronunciation of these roots within a particular dialect. There is a third form of this lexeme, transcribed by the author as truška, but this was only used by speakers near the city of Spohla.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 24 "Doppelähre"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 24 "Double spike (grain)"
description: Map 24 in the series explains where the particular regions within Sorbian speaking Germany contain a Sorbian lexeme for the German word Doppelähre 'double spike (grain)', a particular kind of head found on several varieties of grain.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 28 "Getreide"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 28 "Cereal grains"
description: Map 28 in the series describes where two lexemes for Ger. Getreide 'cereal grains' are spoken in the Sorbian language region of Germany. The most common of these lexemes, spoken in all but the southeast corner of the language area, is a direct loan from German. The other root is of Slavic origin, and is spoken mainly southeast of an isogloss from Säuritz-Radibor-Lippitsch-Nochten.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 36 "Roggenfeld"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 36 "Rye field"
description: Map 36 describes the three words found across Sorbian dialects to refer to a 'rye field' (Ger. Roggenfeld), or more specifically, the agricultural stubble field left being after the harvesting of rye (Ger. Roggenstoppelfeld).

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 38 "Kartoffelfeld (Suffix)"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 38 "Potato field (suffix)"
description: Map 38 in the language atlas explains which suffixes are attached to the various roots for 'potato' used across dialects (see map 39). There are two different suffixes used, split across an approximately east-west isogloss. The suffix used in the Schleifer, Muskau, Nochten, and Hoyerswerda dialects is expanded with -n-, though historically remains closely tied with the suffix used in the northern Sorbian language area.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 46 "Distel"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 46 "Thistle"
description: Map 46 shows the distribution of word forms for 'thistle' (Ger. Distel) in the Sorbian language area. Two roots are found, one of which is common (with phonological variance) over most of the language region, though east of a line from Fehrow-Döbbrick-Cottbus, a different word root is used.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 48 "Kornblume"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 48 "Cornflower"
description: Map 48 of the series describes the distribution of the three main words (and their phonological variants) used in the Sorbian language area to refer to the 'corn flower' (Ger. Kornblume; in botany, centaurea cyanus). The form most commonly used in the southern Sorbian region derives from the proto-Slavic *kostr- meaning 'sharp, pointy'. North of an east-west isogloss, a form derived from *modr is most common. Lastly, a loan translation of the German is also found, especially around Spremberg and Weißwasser.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 59 "untere Enden der Garben"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 59 "Lower ends of sheaves"
description: Map 59 in the series shows where various pronunciations of words in Sorbian deriving from the proto-Slavic *ritь", with the modern meaning of 'the lower end of (grain) sheaves' (Ger. untere Enden der Garben). Nearly the entire region uses varying pronunciations of a simple morpheme deriving from *ritь", while in the southwest corner, a feminine or plural ending is appended.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 61 "Drescher"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 61 "Thresher"
description: Map 61 shows where various dialect forms of Sorbian for 'thresher' (Ger. Drescher). Interesting, in the dialect spoken in Niederlausitz, Mattendorf, Muskau, Nochten, and various small cities in the western part of the Sorbian language area, an [l] is maintained in the modern pronunciations stemming from the historical Slavic root. This feature is not found in the eastern portion of the Sorbian language area.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 62 "Stiel des Dreschfliegels"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 62 "Flail handle"
description: Map 62 in the series displays the various pronunciations of a Sorbian lexeme meaning 'the handle of a flail (for threshing)' (Ger. Stiel des Dreschflegels). The initial consonant's place of articulation and presence or absence of the suffix -ńik results in the major differences across dialects. Both features are split along an approximately east-west isogloss near Senftenberg and Weißwasser.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 63 "Schlegel des Dreschflegels"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 63 "Flail (movable part)"
description: Map 63 shows the various pronunciations of the Sorbian word for 'part of a flail with which one threshes' (Ger. Schlegel des Dreschflegels). All forms derive from proto-Slavic *biti.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 26 "Ripse (Hirse)"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 26 " Ear of millet"
description: Map 26 in the language atlas deals with a particular part of the millet plant, the Ger. Ripse 'panicle'. This can be interpreted as the ear of the millet grain. Interestingly, west of the isogloss from Zahsow-Sielow-Dissen-Turnow-Tauer, the plural form of the Sorbian root is most commonly used, similar to collective nouns. Other parts of the dialect area use a different root, which sometimes means both Ger. Rispe 'panicle' and Traube 'flower/seed cluster'.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 41 "Kartoffelkräutig"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 41 "Potato plant"
description: Map 41 shows where particular lexemes referring to the potato plant (i.e., the stem, leaves, and flowers of a growing potato- not what one would serve at dinner). In addition to the word forms presented on this map, the appropriate word for 'potato' is found in addition to the words mentioned here, lest the meaning is generalized to simply 'plant, plant greenery' (Ger. Kräutig, Kraut). See map 39 for the distribution of roots meaning 'potato' across Sorbian dialects.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 42 "Rübenkräutig"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 42 "Beet plant"
description: Map 42 shows where the various Sorbian word forms for 'beet plant' (Ger. Rübenkräutig) are found. Interestingly, two minimally differing forms, derived from the same historical root dominate the language area except in the Muskau dialect, where a unique form is found. In many areas, these roots can apply to the plant greenery of other root vegetables, tubers, rhizomes, etc.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 44 "Klee"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 44 "Clover"
description: Map 44 of the series describes the words used in the Sorbian language area to refer to 'clover' (Ger. Klee). There are two different Slavic roots used for the plant, split across an approximately east-west isogloss near a line from Forst-Cottbus.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 50 "Melde (atriplex)"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 50 "Atriplex (Saltbush)"
description: Map 50 shows the overall distribution of two different Sorbian lexemes meaning 'atriplex/saltbush' (Ger. Melde (Atriplex)). All but the southwestern portion of the Sorbian language area use a word form deriving from the proto-Slavic *loboda, while the southwestern area uses a root whose etymological origin is uncertain.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 51 "*pomedь 'Meltau'"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 51 "*pomedь 'Mildew'"
description: Map 51 in the series describes the various pronunciations of Sorbian terms deriving from the proto-Slavic *pomedь, meaning 'mildew' (Ger. Meltau).

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 52 "Gabelstiel"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 52 "Pitchfork handle/shaft"
description: Map 52 shows the locations of a particular Sorbian morpheme, found mainly in the northeastern part of the language area (Niederlausitz), which is used to describe the (historically) wooden handle/shaft of a pitchfork (Ger. Gabelstiel).

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 55 "Flachhacke"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 55 "Hoe"
description: Map 55 shows the distribution of various words found in the Niederlausitz region of the Sorbian language area to refer to a small, hand-held hoe used for weeding or digging beets and radishes. Interestingly, five forms are found, some of which contain multiple phonological variants depending on city. All five forms can mean 'hoe' (Ger. Flachhacke), though most of these lexemes also have extended meanings.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 56 "Garbenauflage"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 56 "Grain sheaf array"
description: Map 56 presents the various word forms found in the Sorbian language area for Ger. Garbenauflage, a difficult to translate term best approximated as 'the arraying of sheaves of grain on a barn floor in preparation for threshing'. There are five different roots used, depending on dialect area, some of which also have multiple phonetic realizations.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 69 "Sichel"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 69 "Sickle"
description: Map 69 presents the distribution of six different Sorbian word forms used to describe the 'sickle' (Ger. Sichel).

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 43 "Kartoffelmiete"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 43 "Potato clamp"
description: Map 43 describes the various Sorbian words for the 'potato clamp' (Ger. Kartoffelmiete), in which potatoes are piled and stored over winter. Historically, in Sorbian speaking areas, two methods of potato storage seem to have taken root- one above ground and one below. Potatoes stored above ground in clamps are distinguished by the use of the words kopica, kupa, and romada, while underground potato storage uses the words jama, dol/dow/dowk, and dep. Following the World Wars, potatoes have been stored primarily above ground, though the use of these various word forms stemming back to historical precedent continues.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 64 "Geringe (Körner)"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 64 "poor/weak (grain)"
description: Map 64 shows where two lexemes meaning 'poor/weak (grain)' (Ger. geringe (Körner) are found. In the northern part of the Sorbian language area, a loan from German gering is observed, while in the south the original Slavic word still dominates.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 65 "Häcksel"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 65 "Chaff"
description: Map 65 shows the locations of three different words in Sorbian dialects meaning '[chaff](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaff)' (Ger. Häcksel). The primary Sorbian word derives from proto-Slavic *sěk. In the western and middle portions of the Hoyerswarda dialect, a form stemming from rěz is observed, while in the far northwestern part of the language area, a loan from German is used.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 66 "Strohschneider"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 66 "Straw/chaff cutter"
description: Map 66 shows the words meaning 'straw/chaff cutter' (Ger. Strohschneider), though the authors note that such equipment was long outdated at the time of the gathering of the data used in making the maps. There are two widely used lexemes, split upon an east-west isogloss just north of Spremberg. South of this line, the proto-Slavic root *rěz is observed in the modern words, while to the north, a different root is used.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 67 "Sensenwurf"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 67 "Scythe"
description: Map 67 notes how the Sorbian dialects pronounce 'scythe' (Ger. Sensenwurf). The main difference between dialects is the word formation- many use different suffixes attached to a shared historical root.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 68 "Griff des Sensenwurfes"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 68 "Scythe grip"
description: Map 68 in the series displays the various words used in Sorbian dialects to describe the 'grip of a scythe' (more specifically, the authors point out, 'the grip approximately half way up the shaft held with the right hand') (Ger. Griff des Sensenwurfes). The word forms observed in the middle of the language area are falling out of use in favor of a German loanword.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 70 "Wetzstein"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 70 "Whetstone"
description: Map 70 shows the isogloss splitting various Sorbian dialect's use of different lexemes for 'whetstone' (Ger. Wetzstein). This isogloss is approximately east-west, and is found from Senftenberg to north of Weißwasser.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 71 "Wetzsteinbehälter"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 71 "Whetstone holder"
description: Map 71 shows the various portions of the Sorbian language region where differences in pronunciation for a common root meaning 'whetstone holder commonly worn on a belt' (Ger. Wetzsteinbehälter).

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 74 "reifen"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 74 "to ripen"
description: Map 74 shows the numerous dialectal pronunciations of the Sorbian meaning 'to ripen' (Ger. reifen).

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 25 "Granne"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 25 "Awn"
description: Map 25 describes the distribution of two lexemes in the Sorbian for the [awn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Awn_%28botany%29) of grain (Ger. Granne). One of these lexemes is found in the north and northeastern part of the Sorbian speaking area of Germany, while the second dominates the south and southeastern portions of the language area.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 29 "*jarica"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map NUM "*jarica (proto-Slavic)"
description: Map 29 in the language atlas describes the pronunciations of the proto-Slavic root *jarica 'spring wheat, rye, corn' (Ger. Sommerkorn) in the Sorbian language region at the time of the book's publication. Notable phonological and prosodic changes are found between dialect regions.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 30 "Buchweizen"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 30 "Buckwheat"
description: Map 30 in the series presents two Sorbian word roots used for 'buckwheat' (Ger. Buchweizen). The pronunciation of these roots varies slightly across related dialects, though the overall distribution of these roots are separated across a north-south isogloss in the northern region of the Sorbian language area. Northwestern portions of this area use a Slavic word root, while east of this isogloss, a German loanword is most commonly used.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 31 "Hirse"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 31 "Millet"
description: Map 31 describes the locations of different word roots in Sorbian used to describe the millet plant (Ger. Hirse). Both roots are of Slavic origin. In the northwestern Sorbian language area, a root stemming from proto-Slavic *proso is used. The word <jagły> (and its dialectal phonological variants) is used in the rest of the language region.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 32 "Hirsestroh (Wurzel)"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 32 "Millet straw (root)"
description: Map 32 displays the distribution of the Sorbian root words used in various dialect areas for 'millet straw' (Ger. Hirsestroh). Like in previous maps dealing with cereal grains, there is competition between the proto-Slavic root *proso and *jagl(y). In most Sorbian speaking communities, the modern root derived from *jagl(y) is most common, and the use of the other Sorbian lexeme derived from *proso is declining in use. Most southern parts of the Sorbian language area use neither, as millet farming is not widely practiced in this area.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 35 "Roggenstroh"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 35 "Rye straw"
description: Map 35 presents the adjective accompanying the noun słoma 'straw' in the complex construction meaning 'rye straw' (Ger. Roggenstroh). Four adjectival forms are used across dialects, some containing particularly interesting phonological developments from their common proto-Slavic consonant cluster *rž, including consonant cluster simplification (džyna/žyna forms) and consonant metathesis (žrana).

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 37 "*stŕ̥n-"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 37 "*stŕ̥n-"
description: Map 37 describes the locations in the Sorbian language area in which the lexeme for the agricultural stubble field (Ger. Stoppelfeld), or the stubs of stalks left after harvest, is built with the proto-Slavic root *stŕ̥n-. This root is only found in the southern part of the language area, as a loanword derived from German Stoppel 'stubble' is used in the north.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 39 "Kartoffel"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 39 "Potato"
description: Map 39 displays the seven used word roots for 'potato' (Ger. Kartoffel) in the Sorbian language area. All seven forms derive from historical loans from German: Erdbirne, Kugel, Erdäpfel, Knödel, and Erdbohnen. Curiously, all instances of Erd- in the Sorbian words are apocopated.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 40 "Saatkartoffel"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 40 "Seed potato"
description: Map 40 documents the Sorbian words for 'seed potato', i.e. the planted part of a potato used to induce propagation (Ger. Saatkartoffel). In the Sorbian language area, a complex form including the various dialectal words for potato (Ger. Kartoffel) is used in the southern region, while in the north a different root is used, the meaning of which can also be applied to the more generalized German word Steckling 'cutting of a plant so as to prompt further propagation'.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 45 "*smaga"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 45 "*smaga"
description: Map 45 shows the locations within the Sorbian language area where the historical proto-Slavic root *smaga surfaces in a modern form. Modern iterations of this root are found primarily in the southern Sorbian region, with a variety of meanings. The most commonly cited form means 'clover field' (Ger. Kleebrache). Less common meanings include 'sun tan' and 'sunburn' (Ger. Sonnenbräune, Sonnenbrand), 'burn mark' (Ger. Brandfleck), or even 'freckle' (Ger. Sonnenfleck).

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 53 "Misthacke"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 53 "Pitchfork"
description: Map 53 displays the various dialectal pronuncations of two related Slavic morphemes in Sorbian for 'pitchfork' or a similar implement used for mucking (Ger. Misthacke). These two forms are separated along an approximately east-west isogloss just north of Weißwasser.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 54 "Kartoffelhacke"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 54 "Potato hoe"
description: Map 54 presents the distribution of three lexemes used in Sorbian speaking Germany to refer to the 'potato hoe' (Ger. Kartoffelhacke). South of an isogloss between Cottbus and Forst, the lexeme mótyka (and its phonological variants) is most common. Interestingly, in the northern Niederlausitz region, the Kartoffelhacke and Misthacke (Eng. 'pitchfork') are not differentiated.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 57 "*oklepь"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 57 "*oklepь (Proto-Slavic)"
description: Map 57 of the series presents the modern Sorbian forms, and their meanings, derived from the proto-Slavic *oklepь. The meaning of the modern word forms are most commonly cited as a 'hay bail' (Ger. eine Schütte Stroh) or a 'once-threshed sheaf via flailing' (Ger. einmal durchgedroschene Garbe(n) beim Flegeldreschen).

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 58 "Strohseil"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 58 "Straw rope"
description: Map 58 shows the various pronunciations of words meaning 'straw rope' (Ger. Strohseil) in the Sorbian language area. The main isogloss occurs on a line from Weigersdorf-Zimpel-Bärwalde-Neustadt-Zerre, which separates the dialects based on the insertion of [t] into the word root.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 60 "Getreidepuppe"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 60 "Stook (of grain)"
description: Map 60 presents the distribution of words across Sorbian dialects referring to stooks (i.e. piles) of mowed grain, in sheaves, in order to dry and ripen before further processing (Ger. Getreidepuppe(n)). The entirety of the Sorbian language area uses German loanwords to describe these agricultural structures, though two different roots were loaned: in the northwest, a loanword derived from Ger. Haufe 'pile', while the rest of the area uses a word derived from Ger. Puppe 'stook'.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 33 "Hirsestroh (subst. Suffix)"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 33 "Millet straw (subst. suffix)"
description: Map 33 in the language atlas details the areas where various substantival suffixes attach to the noun root for 'millet straw' (Ger. Hirsestroh). This noun root rarely occurs as a single morpheme, as nearly all dialects append some form of a substantival ending.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 47 "Ackerrettich"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 47 "Wild radish"
description: Map 47 shows the isogloss between two Sorbian lexemes both meaning 'wild radish' (Ger. Ackerrettich). North of the isogloss from Michalken-Maukendorf-Bärwalde-Mochholz, a loanword from German is used, while south of this line a word of Slavic origin dominates. Interestingly, in the area surrounding Weißwasser, either the plant itself is unknown, or, in any case, a unique word for it is not found.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Altas): Karte 49 "Quecke"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 49 "Couch grass"
description: Map 49 presents the distribution of Sorbian pronuncations for 'couch grass' (Ger. Quecke, in botany elymus/triticum repens). All dialectal pronunciations stem from the same historical root, though vowel change and loss of palatalization have created several different pronuncations across dialects.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 72 "Dengelhammer"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 72 "Peening hammer"
description: Map 72 shows where different lexemes are found in the Sorbian language area to refer to the process of [peening](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peening) metal, that is, making it stronger by hammering out impurities. The tool used, the 'peening hammer' (Ger. Dengelhammer) has two different word forms in Sorbian, depending on dialect- one being a loan from German, the other being a native Slavic root. The isogloss is approximately north-south across the region.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 73 "Dengeleisen"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 73 "Peening iron"
description: Map 73 in the series shows how the various Sorbian dialects across the Sorbian language area refer to a '[peening](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peening) iron', that is, a small device normally lain across a large stone against which one would lay a scythe for peening (Ger. Dengeleisen).

name: Dogon Villages - Endonyms, Exonyms, and Primary Languages Spoken (Heath)
title: Dogon Villages in Mali and Burkina Faso (Endonyms, Exonyms, and Primary Language Spoken)
description: According to the [Dogon Languages](http://dogonlanguages.org/) project website, approximately twenty Dogon languages exist, but due to terrain and climate, many villages have not yet been suitably surveyed. This map shows villages (listed by endonym and exonym) as well as the dominant language variety of each surveyed village; see the [Dogon and Bangime Linguistics](http://dogonlanguages.org/#languages) website for more information.
source: GPS Coordinate Data and [Dogon and Bangime Linguistics](http://dogonlanguages.org/)
license: GPS Coordinate Data provided by Jeff Heath on behalf of the [Dogon project](http://dogonlanguages.org/).
contact: Jeff Heath, University of Michigan, [Dogon and Bangime Linguistics](http://dogonlanguages.org/)
creator: Jeff Heath
note: Each map in this series contains a high quality satellite relief map which will appear as the user zooms in and may take some time to load.

name: Areas where Language Spoken is Unknown at the Time of Contact
title: Areas Where Language Spoken is Unknown at the Time of Contact
description: The areas pictured display locations where languages spoken at the time of contact were unknown.
related: This folder (Central and South America: Time of Contact) contains other maps showing linguistic subgroups at the time of contact. This map is designed to work with other maps in this folder. They should be overlaid on each other for a complete picture of the region.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 2 "Heuschober"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 2 "Haystack"
description: There are two major lexemes in Sorbian for 'haystack'. This map shows the distribution of these two major forms, as well as several pronunciations of them. Isoglosses are marked.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 3 "schobern"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 3 "to make a haystack"
description: This map details the various forms of the verb schobern 'to make a haystack', as spoken in Sorbian speaking Germany.

name: Cholónan in South America at the Time of Contact
description: The areas pictured display locations of where Cholónan languages were spoken when they were first encountered and knowledge of them was recorded. As specified in Asher and Moseley, the time of contact varied for each language; most of the coastal languages were first identified during the 16th and 17th centuries, although some languages in the interior of South America became known much more recently during the 20th century (Kaufman 2007).
related:
This folder (Central and South America: Time of Contact) contains other maps 
showing linguistic subgroups and their time of contact. The maps may be 
overlaid on each other for a more complete picture.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 6 "Ruhrhacken"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 4 "Ruhrhaken"
description: This map shows the distribution of three Sorbian lexemes used for an archaic farming implement, the Ruhrhaken, or a sort of plow, resembling a hook (haken), especially used for potato farming. Because this farming tool is no longer in use, the words used originally for Ruhrhaken specifically now, often times, have more generalized meanings related to plowing.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 12 "wosrědk 'Ackerbeet'"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 12

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 17 "Samen"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 17 "Seed"
description: May 17 describes the distributions of two lexemes meaning 'seed' (Ger. Samen) in Sorbian speaking areas. There is a major isogloss on a line from Schmogrow-Briesen-Gulben-Cottbus-Groß Lieskow-Tranitz that separates the areas where the lexemes *sěmę and *sěvo are primarily used to refer to Ger. Samen.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 21 "Halm"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 21 "Stem"
description: Map 21 in this series describes four major dialectal divisions in the Sorbian lexemes (and their various pronunciations in closely related dialects) for the German translation Halm 'stem'.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 19 "keimen"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 19 "to germinate"
description: Map 19 shows the distribution of several Sorbian words given as equivalencies to the German keimen 'to geminate'. The lexemes used to describe germination are split between three major dialect areas comprising the following cities: 1) Schliefe, Muksau, Hoyerswerda; 2) Nochten, Bärwalde, Lieske, Zimpel, Mücka; 3) other cities of Sorbian-speaking Germany. In Sollschwitz, a unique form is observed.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 22 "Ähre"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 22 "Ear (of grain)"
description: Map 22 of the series describes the Sorbian forms of a word translated by the authors as Ger. Ähre which can be interpreted as an ear of grain, or the type of structure the head of a particular variety of grain has. Notably, north of the main isogloss line in this map, the masculine form of the Sorbian root is most common, while south of this line, the feminine form dominates local speech.

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 27 "Roggen"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 27 "Rye"
description: Map 27 in the series documents the two lexemes used in various parts of the Sorbian speaking community referring to 'rye' (Ger. Roggen). Interestingly, in some dialect areas, the same root applies to both 'rye' (Ger. Roggen) and the more generalized '(cereal) grain' (Ger. Getreide).

name: Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 34 "Haferstroh"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 34 "Oat straw"
description: Map 34 in the series presents the pronunciations and locations of two widely propagated terms for 'oat straw' (Ger. Haferstroh) in the Sorbian language area. The form most commonly used in the northern part of the Sorbian language are derives from the adjective wowsny, whereas in the southern part the same word is described with the complex construction wowsna słoma. Each lexeme has multiple phonological variations.

name: Language Atlas of China: Hakka Group
Sorbischer Sprachatlas (Sorbian Language Atlas): Karte 12 "wosrědk 'Ackerbeet'"
title: Sorbian Language Atlas: Map 20 "Eye of a Potato"
description: Map 20 describes the various words used in Sorbian dialects to describe the (Ger.) Keim der Kartoffel 'the eye of the potato', visible when potatoes begin to germinate (Ger. keimen, see map 19). There are four different lexemes documented, one of which is a German loanword into Sorbian.

name: Sechura-Katakáoan in South America at the Time of Contact
title: Sechura-Katakáoan in South America at the Time of Contact
description: The areas pictured display locations of where Sechura-Katakáoan languages were spoken when they were first encountered and knowledge of them was recorded. As specified in Asher and Moseley, the time of contact varied for each language; most of the coastal languages were first identified during the 16th and 17th centuries, although some languages in the interior of South America became known much more recently during the 20th century (Kaufman 2007).
related:
This folder (Central and South America: Time of Contact) contains other maps 
showing linguistic subgroups and their time of contact. The maps may be 
overlaid on each other for a more complete picture.

name: Tukánoan in South America at the Time of Contact
title: Tukánoan in South America at the Time of Contact
description: The areas pictured display locations of where Tukánoan languages were spoken when they were first encountered and knowledge of them was recorded. As specified in Asher and Moseley, the time of contact varied for each language; most of the coastal languages were first identified during the 16th and 17th centuries, although some languages in the interior of South America became known much more recently during the 20th century (Kaufman 2007). The area identified as Jauna... represents the following languages: Jaúna, Kubewa (Cubeo), Makuna-Erulia, Yapuá, Kueretú, Desana-Siriana (Desano), Bará-Tuyuka, Karapaná (Carapana), Tukano (Tucano), Wanana-Pirá.
related:

overlaid on each other for a more complete picture.

name: Languages and the Anglo-Saxon Conquest (450-700 AD)
description:
This map shows the linguistic effects of the quickly changing geo-political boundaries of the island of Britain during the Anglo-Saxon conquest.
        There are multiple layers in this map. For readability, only the first two layers have been turned on by default. To view other layers, please check or uncheck desired layers in the legend on the right.
source: Kessler, Peter. 2007. Post Roman Britain: The Anglo-Saxon Conquest in Maps. [Online](http://www.historyfiles.co.uk/FeaturesBritain/BritishMapAD450-700.htm).
